§ 4.134.  A budget message relative to the condition, reasons, etc., connected with the estimates for the ensuing year together with a work program showing the undertakings to be begun and those to be completed during the next year. 
§ 4.135.  Such other information as may be requested by council. 
§ 4.14.  Introduction, etc., of appropriation ordinances. At the same time that the city manager shall submit a general fund and/or utility budget he shall introduce appropriation ordinances listing the appropriation for each department, utility, branch, board or commission, and such budget, or budgets, shall act as the supporting schedules for the appropriation ordinances. (Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
§ 4.15.  Hearing on budget plan; insertion, etc., of items. A public hearing on the budget plan as a whole shall be held by the council within thirty (30) days after its submission to the council but not until a resume of the proposed budgets and notice of such hearing shall have been published at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least ten (10) days prior to such hearing. After the conclusion of the public hearing the council may insert new items of expenditure or may increase, decrease, or strike out any items of expenditure in the budgets except that for debt service. 
§ 4.16.  Approval of budgets and adoption of appropriation ordinances. Within forty (40) days, but in no event later than the thirty-first day of May, the council shall approve, upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the membership of the council, a general fund and/or utility budget and adopt appropriation ordinances. If for any reason the council fails to approve the budgets on or before such date, then the budgets as submitted by the city manager shall be the budgets for the ensuing year and the appropriation ordinances recommended by the city manager shall have the same force and effect as if the same had been adopted by the council. 
§ 4.17.  Additional appropriations. The council may, after referring to the city manager for a recommendation, make additional appropriations during the fiscal year upon the affirmative vote of four (4) members of the council. (Acts 1962, ch. 164) 
§ 4.18.  Lapse of unexpended, etc., annual appropriations. Any portion of an annual appropriation, except for capital expenditures, remaining unexpended and unencumbered at the close of the fiscal year, shall lapse. 
§ 4.19.  Program of proposed capital improvement projects. The capital budget shall contain a program previously acted upon by the city planning commission, as provided in section 7.101 of this Charter, of proposed capital improvement projects, for the ensuing fiscal year and for the four (4) fiscal years thereafter, with his recommendations as to the means of financing the improvements proposed for the ensuing fiscal year. The council shall have power to accept with or without amendments or reject the proposed program and proposed means of financing for the ensuing fiscal year but, except in the case of emergency as provided in Article 3 of this Charter, the council shall not authorize any capital improvement project or make any appropriation therefor unless the appropriation for such project is included in the capital budget as adopted by it. The council shall take final action on the capital budget not later than the twenty-eighth day after the date prescribed for the adoption of the general fund budget. No appropriation for a capital improvement project contained in the capital budget shall lapse until the purpose for which the appropriation was made shall have been accomplished or abandoned, provided that any project shall be deemed to have been abandoned if three (3) fiscal years elapse without any expenditure from or encumbrance of the appropriation therefor. Any such lapsed appropriation shall be applied to the payment of any indebtedness incurred in financing the project concerned and the next capital budget. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to limit the power of the city council to originate or initiate capital improvements. 
Sec. 4.2. - Bids and purchases. 
    At least two (2) bids shall be secured on all purchases involving more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) except, when the council orders a different procedure; when only one bid can be secured; and in cases of emergency. The fact that bids are received does not make it mandatory that the low bid be accepted in all cases. The council must approve purchase before placing order if low bid is not accepted. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
Sec. 4.3. - Independent audit. 
    Prior to the end of each fiscal year the council shall designate qualified certified public accountants or the auditor of public accounts of the Commonwealth of Virginia, who, as of the end of the fiscal year, shall make an independent audit of accounts and other evidence of financial transactions of the city government and shall mail a copy of their report to each member of the city council and to the city manager. The auditors shall postaudit the books and documents kept by the treasurer and any separate or subordinate accounts kept by any other office, department or agency of the city government. 
State Law reference- Independent audit, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2511. 
Sec. 4.4. - Tax liens; remedies for collection of taxes. 
    A lien shall exist on all real estate and personal property within the corporate limits for taxes, levies, and assessments in favor of the city, together with all penalties and interest at the rate of six (6) per centum due thereon from the end of the year for which the same were assessed and the procedure for collecting said taxes, for selling real estate for city taxes and for the redemption of real estate sold for city taxes shall be the same as provided in the general law for the state to the same extent as if the provisions of said general law were herein set out at length. The said city and its treasurer shall have the benefit of other and additional remedies for the collection of city taxes which are now or hereafter may be granted or permitted under the general law. All goods and chattels wheresoever found may be distrained and sold for taxes and licenses assessed and due thereon; and no deed of trust or mortgage upon goods and chattels or real estate shall prevent the same from being distrained and sold for taxes and licenses assessed against the grantor in such deed while such goods and chattels remain in the grantor's possession. 
Sec. 4.5. - Tax rate or levy. 
    The council of the City of Buena Vista shall, prior to the thirty-first day of December of each year, or at its option prior to the first day of July if a fiscal year of July one to June thirty be adopted, adopt and fix the rate of taxation or levy on all personal property situate within the said city which is classified as machinery, tools, motor vehicles, or mobile trailers, and shall likewise prior to said date adopt and fix the rate of taxation or levy on all public service corporation property situate within the said city, and upon the value of the shares of stock of all banks situate within the said city, as provided by general law for the calendar year commencing on the first day of January of the year next succeeding. 
    The council for the City of Buena Vista shall, prior to the thirtieth day of June of each year, adopt and fix for the ensuing fiscal year the rate of taxation or levy on all real property situate within the said city, as provided by general law for the fiscal year commencing on the first day of July of the next succeeding year. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361; Acts 1972, ch. 257; Acts 1975, ch. 169, § 1) 
Editor's note- The tax on bank stock has been replaced by a tax on the net capital of banks. See Code of Virginia § 58.1-1200 et seq. 
ARTICLE 5. - ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE 

Sec. 5.1. - Circuit court-Continuation; jurisdiction, authority and powers. 
    The circuit court of the City of Buena Vista as presently created and established by the general laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia shall be continued and the said circuit court shall have the jurisdiction, authority and powers now or hereafter conferred upon and vested in the circuit courts of the several counties and cities, and the corporation courts of the several cities, by the general laws of the said commonwealth. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
State Law reference- Circuit courts, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-500 et seq. 
Sec. 5.102. - Same-Compensation of judge. 
    The City of Buena Vista shall pay such annual salary unto the judge of the circuit court of the City of Buena Vista as shall be fixed by the council of the said city and the same shall be paid in addition to the pro rata portion or share of the regular salary of such judge allocated unto the said city by the general laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia. Provided, however, the foregoing annual salary shall not be reduced or diminished during the term of office of the said judge. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
Secs. 5.103-5.7. - (Repealed). 
Editor's note- Sections 5.103-5.7 of the Charter were repealed by Acts 1975, ch. 169. Sections 5.103-5.4 formerly made provision for a municipal court, a juvenile and domestic relations court and justices of the peace. Sections 5.5-5.6 formerly made provision for a joint trial justice system with Rockbridge County. Section 5.7 validated acts of the civil and police justice. 
Secs. 5.8-5.906. - (Repealed). 
Editor's note- Sections 5.8-5.906 of the Charter were repealed by Acts 1954, ch. 361. 
ARTICLE 5A. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Acts 1954, ch. 361, designated sections 5.907-5.910 as "Article 5A. Police Department." 

Sec. 5.907. - Generally. 
    The police force shall be composed of a superintendent or chief of police and of such officers, patrolmen and other employees as the council may determine. The superintendent or chief of police shall have the immediate direction and control of the said force, subject, however, to the supervision of the city manager and to such rules, regulations and orders as the said city manager may prescribe. The superintendent or chief of police shall issue all orders, rules and regulations for the government of the whole force. In case of the disability of the superintendent or chief of police to perform his duties by reason of sickness, absence from the city or other cause, the city manager shall designate some member of the police force to act as superintendent or chief of police during such disability, and the officer so designated shall serve without additional compensation. The members of the police force shall be appointed and may be removed by the city manager. Each member of the said force, both rank and file[,] shall have issued to him a warrant of appointment signed by the city manager, in which the date of his appointment shall be stated, and such warrant shall be his commission. Each member of the said force shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe an oath before the clerk of the circuit court that he will faithfully without fear or favor perform the duties of this office, and such oath shall be filed with the clerk of said court and preserved with the records of his office. And, in addition, the several officers of the said force shall if so required by the council, give bond in such penalty and with such security as the council may by ordinance prescribe. 
Sec. 5.908. - Special police, special detectives, etc. 
    No person except as otherwise provided by general law or by this Charter shall act as special police, special detective or other special police officer for any purpose whatsoever, except upon written authority from the city manager; such authority[,] when conferred, shall be exercised only under the direction and control of the superintendent or chief of police and for a specified time, provided, however, that the council may from time to time designate the maximum number of such special police, special detectives or other special police officers. 
State Law reference- Auxiliary police force, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1731. 
Sec. 5.909. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The officers and privates constituting the police force of said city shall be, and they are, hereby vested with all of the power and authority which pertains to the office of constable at common law in taking cognizance of and in enforcing criminal laws of the state and the ordinances and regulations of said city and it shall be the duty of each such officer and private to use his best endeavors to prevent the commission within the said city of offenses against the laws of said state, and against the ordinances and regulations of said city; to observe and enforce all such laws, ordinances and regulations; to detect and arrest offenders against the same; to preserve the good order of said city and to secure the inhabitants thereof from violence and the property therein from injury. Such policemen shall have no power or authority in civil matters, but shall execute any criminal warrant or warrant of arrest and summons in criminal cases that may be placed in his [their] hands, by any justice of the city and shall make due return thereof. 
Sec. 5.910. - Uniforms, badges, etc. 
    The city manager shall prescribe the uniforms and badges for the members of the police force, and direct the manner in which a member of said force shall be armed. Any person other than a member of said force who shall wear such uniform or badge as may be prescribed as aforesaid, may be subjected to such fine or imprisonment, or both, as may be prescribed by the council by ordinance. 
ARTICLE 6. - SCHOOLS 

Sec. 6.1. - Further provisions as to wards; each ward to be separate school district. 
Editor's note- This section was repealed by Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 2. 
Sec. 6.2. - Members of school board. 
    The school board shall consist of seven members who shall be elected from the city at large. In compliance with a November 2, 1992, referendum, members of the school board shall be elected or appointed in the manner as hereinafter set forth. 
    The terms of the five members of the present school board which are now scheduled to expire on June 30, 1994, and June 30, 1995, shall all expire on June 30, 1994. The remaining two members of the present school board whose terms expire on June 30, 1996, shall remain in office until June 30, 1996. The other five members whose terms will expire on June 30, 1994, shall be replaced in a manner as hereinafter set forth. The present term of the at-large member expires on June 30, 1994. At that time the city council shall appoint an at-large member to serve on the school board for a term expiring on June 30, 1996. 
    At the regular municipal election to be held on the first Tuesday in May 1994, and every four years thereafter, four school board members shall be elected for a term of four years beginning on the first day of July next following their election. 
    At the regular municipal election to be held on the first Tuesday in May 1996, and every four years thereafter, three school board members shall be elected for a term of four years beginning on the first day of July next following their election. 
(Acts 1973, ch. 82; Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 1) 
Editor's note- Election date was changed to November in accordance with Code of Virginia, §§ 24.2-222.1 and 24.2-223 which supersedes the Charter and allows for the modification of the election date to November without a formal change to the Charter. 
State Law reference- Alternative election of mayor and council at November general election, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-222.1; alternative election of school board members at November general election to coincide with election of the governing body, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-223. 
Sec. 6.201. - Regulations as to school district, etc., applicable in the event the city is divided into more than two wards. 
Editor's note- This section was repealed by Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 2. 
Sec. 6.202. - Length of service. 
Editor's note- This section was repealed by Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 2. 
Sec. 6.203. - Current terms of members of school boards. 
Editor's note- This section was repealed by Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 2. 
Sec. 6.3. - Powers, duties, etc., of school board. 
    The establishment, maintenance, and operation of a system of free public schools within the city of Buena Vista shall be under the control of the school board, appointed by the city council or elected in accordance with the provisions of this charter, the Constitution of Virginia, the laws of the Commonwealth, and the regulations of the state board of education; and said board shall have all the rights, privileges, powers, and duties granted or empowered by the said provisions, Constitution, laws, and regulations; and nothing in this charter shall negate any rights, privileges, powers, or duties granted or empowered to the school board by said provisions, Constitution, laws, and regulations; and neither shall the school board have any such rights, privileges, powers, and duties not provided by said provisions, Constitution, laws and regulations 
(Acts 1994, ch. 91, § 1) 
State Law reference- Public school system, Code of Virginia, § 22.1-1 et seq. 
ARTICLE 7. - PLANNING, ZONING, SUBDIVISION, ETC., CONTROL, ETC. 

Sec. 7.1. - Powers of council as to master plan, zoning and subdivisions and as to building, electrical, plumbing, heating, etc., codes. 
    The city council, in addition to any other powers, shall have and may exercise all other powers which now or may hereafter apply to cities under the Constitution and general laws of this state as pertains to the following: 
§ 7.101.  The power to adopt, administer, and enforce by ordinance a master plan for the comprehensive long-range development of the city, provided, however, that any such master plan so adopted shall first have been subjected to a thorough study of not less than one year by a planning commission or board appointed for that specific purpose; and, provided further that such master plan after adoption shall not be later altered except by referendum following at least one year of study by a planning commission or board appointed by the city council for that specific purpose. 
§ 7.102.  The power to adopt, administer and enforce, by ordinance, a comprehensive zoning plan for the control of location, type, use[,] height, area, bulk, and arrangement of all structures, buildings, improvements to land and premises, and to provide for a zoning board of appeals. 
§ 7.103.  The power to adopt, administer and enforce, by ordinance, a comprehensive plan for the regulation of all subdivisions of land within the city, or outside the city when served by the city with utilities including any of the following: Water, sewage lines, fire protection or safety protection. 
§ 7.104.  The power to adopt, administer and enforce, by ordinance, any building code, and/or electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilating, fire safety or other code for the safety, uniformity, appearance, convenience, and construction, alteration, or repair of any building, or structure used by the public or for private use within the city unless otherwise provided for in this Charter. 
ARTICLE 8. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 8.1. - Officers, etc., to hold over until appointment, etc., of successors. 
    Whenever under the provisions of this Charter any officer of the city or member of any board or commission is elected or appointed for a fixed term, except the mayor and vice-mayor, such officer or member shall continue to hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
Sec. 8.2. - Continuation in effect of ordinances, etc. 
    All ordinances of the city and all rules, regulations, contracts and orders legally made by any department, board, commission or officer of the city, in force at the effective date of this Charter, insofar as they or any portion thereof are not inconsistent herewith, shall remain in force until amended or repealed in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. 
Sec. 8.3. - Application of general law to city and officers thereof. 
    The City of Buena Vista and all the officers thereof elected or appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Act [Charter] shall be clothed with all the powers and subject to all the provisions of general law not in express conflict with the provisions of this Act [Charter]. 
Sec. 8.4. - Separability of parts, sections, etc., of Charter. 
    If any clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part of this Act [Charter] shall, for any reason, be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of said Act [Charter], but shall be confined in its operations to the clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which said judgment shall have been rendered. 
Sec. 8.5. - How Charter cited. 
    This Act [Charter] and all amendments thereto may for all purposes be referred to or cited as the City of Buena Vista Charter of 1952. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
Sec. 8.6. - Construction of references to particular sections of Code of Virginia. 
    The reference herein to any section of the Code of Virginia shall be construed to mean such section as it existed January 1, 1952, provided that this shall not apply as to any section referred to in any subsequent amendment of this Charter when any such section of the Code of Virginia is referred to as amended, in which event such section shall be construed to mean such Code section as it exists on January one of the year in which the reference is made. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361) 
Sec. 8.7. - Construction of references to particular sections, etc., of Charter. 
    All references to a specific section or subsection of the City of Buena Vista Charter of 1952, herein contained[,] shall be construed to refer to such specific section or subsection as the same may be now or hereafter amended. 
(Acts 1954, ch. 361)

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of the City of Buena Vista, Virginia," and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Buena Vista Code." 
(Code 1967, § 1-1; Code 1981, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to codify and recodify its ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the interpretation and construction of this Code and of all ordinances and resolutions of the city, the following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing with such surety, if any, as the city council may direct, shall be sufficient. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the city, as it now exists or as it may be amended in the future. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Buena Vista, in the County of Rockbridge and the State of Virginia. 
    Code. Whenever the term "Code" is referred to, without further qualification, it means the Code of the City of Buena Vista, Virginia, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is a Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    Council, city council. The term "council" or "city council" means the city council of the City of Buena Vista, Virginia. 
    County. The term "county" means the County of Rockbridge in the State of Virginia. 
    Director of public health. The term "director of public health" means the director of public health of the City of Buena Vista or authorized representative. 
    Following. The term "following," when used by way of reference to any section, shall be construed to mean next following that in which such reference is made. 
    Gender. A term importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to corporations, etc., as well as to males. 
    Health department. The term "health department" means the City of Buena Vista health department or as designated. 
    In the city. The term "in the city" means any territory or jurisdiction of which for the exercise of its regulatory power has been conferred on the city by public or private law. 
    Joint authority. Terms purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise expressly stated. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Number. A term importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; and a term importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Occupant or tenant. The term "occupant" or "tenant," applied to a building or land, means any person who holds a written or oral lease of or actually occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Officers, employees, departments, committees, boards, etc. Whenever reference is made to a particular officer, employee, department, committee, board, commission or other agency, without further qualification, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the term "of the City of Buena Vista, Virginia." A reference to a specific officer shall include that officer's duly authorized deputies and agents. 
    Official time standard. Whenever particular hours are specified in this Code relating to the time within which an act shall or shall not be performed by any person, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" includes a firm, partnership, association of persons, corporation, organization or any other group acting as a unit. 
    Preceding. The term "preceding," when used by way of reference to any section, means next preceding that in which such reference is made. 
    Property. The term "property" means real, personal or mixed property. 
    Public grounds. The term "public grounds" means the parks and all public lands owned by the city and those parts of public places which do not form travelled parts of streets as defined in this section. 
    Shall. The term "shall" shall be mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write, his name being written near it and being witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
    State Code. References to the "State Code" or the "Code of Virginia" means the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. 
    State, commonwealth. The term "state" or "commonwealth" means the State of Virginia. 
    Street. The term "street" includes avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city, and means the entire width thereof between abutting property lines. It shall be construed to include a sidewalk or footpath, unless the contrary is expressed or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. 
    Swear, sworn. The term "swear" or "sworn" shall be equivalent to the term "affirm" or "affirmed" in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Written, in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" includes typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of representing terms and letters. 
(Code 1967, § 1-2; Code 1981, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Similar rules of construction and definitions, Code of Virginia, § 1-200 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere catchterms to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1967, § 1-5; Code 1981, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to sections of State Code, Code of Virginia, § 1-217. 
Sec. 1-4. - References to chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
    Whenever reference is made to a section by number only (e.g., "section 1-1"), without further qualification, it shall be construed as referring to that section of this Code. All references to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1967, § 1-2; Code 1981, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    Reference and editor's notes following certain chapters, articles, divisions or sections are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Provisions of Code construed as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the Buena Vista City Code adopted September 24, 1981, and all ordinances adopted subsequent thereto and included herein, shall be construed as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1967, § 1-4; Code 1981, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-8. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any ordinance granting any franchise or right; 
(3)  Any ordinance appropriating funds, levying or imposing taxes or relating to business licenses or an annual budget; 
(4)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city; 
(5)  Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement or assessments therefor; 
(6)  The land development regulations as contained in part III of this Code, or any amendment thereto, and including amendments to the zoning map and ordinances zoning or rezoning specific property; 
(7)  Any ordinance relating to cemeteries; 
(8)  Any ordinance adopting or amending a park land use plan or a comprehensive plan or master plan for the city, or relating to floodplains; 
(9)  Any ordinance relating to the salaries of the city officers or employees, personnel policies, retirement plans or other benefits; 
(10)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city; 
(11)  Any ordinance regarding motor vehicle or traffic regulations for specific streets; 
(12)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; or 
(13)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the office of the clerk of the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-9. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinance or resolution which repealed another. 
    When an ordinance or resolution which repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance or resolution shall not be revived without express terms to that effect. 
(Code 1981, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-11. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by municipal personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the terms "this ordinance" or terms of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Authority to supplement Code, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433. 
Sec. 1-12. - Copies of Code and supplements to be available for public inspection. 
    At least one copy of this Code and of every supplement thereto shall be kept in the office of the clerk of the city council and shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433. 
Sec. 1-13. - Extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(a)  The city council declares as its legislative intent of the past and for the future that all ordinances enacted making it a criminal offense to do certain things were enacted not only to regulate conduct within the corporate limits of the city but likewise to regulate conduct in all parks, playgrounds, play fields, recreational facilities, cemeteries, airports, schools and other public property of the city whether located within the corporate limits or not, which legislation has been and will in the future be passed pursuant to section 2.420 of the Charter of the city. 
(b)  This section is adopted as clarification of the purpose of criminal ordinances enacted by the city council for the express purpose of giving jurisdiction to the general district court and the circuit court of the city for trial of all violations of, and offenses against, the ordinances of the city committed within one mile of the corporate limits in all parks, playgrounds, play fields, recreational facilities, cemeteries, airports, schools and other public property of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 1-10; Ord. No. 74-6, 10-24-1974) 
Charter reference- Jurisdiction of city, § 2.420. 
Sec. 1-14. - Classification of and penalties for violations; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city, or rule or regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or an offense, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or an offense, and no specific class of misdemeanor or penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine of not more than $2,500.00, or by imprisonment for not more than 12 months, or by both such fine and imprisonment; provided, however, that such penalty shall not exceed the penalty prescribed by general law for a like offense. 
(b)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the city or any rule or regulation promulgated by any officer or agency of the city, under authority duly vested in such officer or agency, it is provided that a violation of any provision thereof shall constitute a Class 1, 2, 3 or 4 misdemeanor, such violation shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  Class 1 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $2,500.00, or by confinement in jail for not more than 12 months, or by both such fine and confinement. 
(2)  Class 2 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or by confinement in jail for not more than six months, or by both such fine and confinement. 
(3)  Class 3 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $500.00. 
(4)  Class 4 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $250.00. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, each day any violation of this Code or any such ordinance, rule, regulation or order continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Wherever authorized by law, the penalties provided in this section shall apply to violations occurring inside or outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 10-1; Code 1981, § 1-11) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prescribe punishment for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1429; classification of misdemeanors and punishment therefor, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-9, 18.2-11; authority of city to provide penalties for violation of ordinances and provisions similar to subsection (c) of this section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1429; authority of court trying case, upon conviction, to require bond conditioned that the person convicted will not violate the ordinance for the breach of which he was convicted for a period of not more than one year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1430; injunctive relief for continuing violations of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1432. 
Sec. 1-15. - Assessment of costs or fees. 
    The judge of the general district court of the city shall, in all cases involving violations of the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city or the collection of taxes or assessments due and owing to the city, or the collection of any other debts due and owing to the city, assess the same costs or fees in connection with the trial of such cases, as are provided by the laws of the state, so made and provided. 
(Code 1967, § 10-2; Code 1981, § 1-12) 
State Law reference- District court fees, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-354. 
Sec. 1-16. - Liability of corporations, etc., and agents for violations. 
(a)  Any violation of this Code by any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization, while acting within the scope of his office or employment, shall in every case also be deemed to be a violation by such corporation, association or organization. 
(b)  Any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization shall be subject and liable to punishment, as well as such corporation or unincorporated association or organization, for the violation by it of any provision of this Code, where such violation was the act or omission, or the result of the act, omission or order of any such person. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-17. - Severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 1-3; Code 1981, § 1-14) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Form of government, § 1.2; powers of the city, art. 2; administration and government, art. 3; financial administration, art. 4; administration of justice, art. 5. 
State Law reference- General powers of cities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1100 et seq.; local government officers, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1500 et seq.; extending police power of city beyond corporate limits, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1725. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Signing and sealing of deeds, contracts, etc. 
    Except where otherwise provided, when any deed, contract or other instrument has been authorized or accepted by the city council by ordinance or resolution, adopted and approved in the manner prescribed by law, and the execution of such instrument on behalf of the city requires the signature of the city, the treasurer and the finance officer are hereby authorized to sign such deed, contract or other instrument in the name and on behalf of the city. Except as otherwise provided, in all cases when it is necessary by law or custom that the corporate seal of the city be affixed to any such deed, contract or other instrument, the clerk of the city council is authorized to affix the corporate seal of the city to such deed, contract or other instrument and to attest such corporate seal so affixed. 
(Code 1967, § 2-2; Code 1981, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- City manager authorized to act as purchasing agent, § 3.914; bids and purchases, § 4.2. 
Sec. 2-2. - Execution of checks. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all checks drawn against any account of the city shall be signed by the treasurer or deputy treasurer and the city manager or finance officer. 
(Code 1967, § 2-59; Code 1981, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-3. - Holidays. 
(a)  Except for employees of the police department, the city shall follow the state holiday schedule. 
(b)  In the event any such holiday shall fall on Sunday, such holiday shall be observed the Monday next succeeding such holiday. 
(Code 1967, § 2-1; Code 1981, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Legal holidays, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3300. 
Sec. 2-4. - Returned check charge. 
    The city shall charge a return check fee of $50.00 per check plus any fees incurred by the city. 
(Ord. of 7-13-2006) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose fee for returned checks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106. 
Secs. 2-5-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Council, §§ 3.3-3.9. 
State Law reference- Governing bodies generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1400 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-26. - One office to be held at a time. 
    Councilmembers not to hold more than one office, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1534, 15.2-1535. 
Sec. 2-27. - Removal from office. 
    By the affirmative vote of two-thirds of its entire membership, the city council may remove a member from office for malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in office, commission of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude or intoxication or other incapacity when required to serve the city. 
(Code 1981, § 2-21) 
Secs. 2-28-2-57. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Council meetings and rules of procedure, § 3.9. 
State Law reference- Open meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3700 et seq. 

Sec. 2-58. - Regular. 
    The city council shall meet in regular session on the first and third Thursdays of each month at 6:00 p.m.; provided, however, that the city council may by resolution adopted at any previous regular or special meeting dispense with any specific regular meeting. The city council's place of meeting shall be the city council chamber at and in the city hall or at any other place designated by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-4; Code 1981, § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-59. - Special. 
    Pursuant to Charter § 3.9, special meetings of the city council may be called by the mayor or any four members of the city council. The clerk of the city council shall prepare a notice of the special session stating time, place and specific statement of items of business to be transacted, and this notice shall be served personally upon each member of the city council and the city manager, or left at their usual places of residence, at least two hours before the time of meeting. It shall also be the duty of the clerk of the city council to make diligent effort to notify each member of the city council in person, either by telephone or otherwise, of such a special session. 
(Code 1967, § 2-5; Code 1981, § 2-32) 
State Law reference- Notice of meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3707. 
Sec. 2-60. - Seating arrangement. 
    City councilmembers shall occupy the respective seats in the city council chamber assigned to them by the mayor, but any two or more members may exchange seats by joining in a written notice to the mayor to that effect. 
(Code 1967, § 2-14; Code 1981, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-61. - Absent members. 
    In the event that a number less than a quorum shall convene at a regular or special meeting of the city council, any member of the city council present may cause to be issued a subpoena, directed to the city sheriff, requiring the attendance of any member so absent. The city sheriff shall forthwith serve such subpoena and compel the attendance of the absent member. 
(Code 1967, § 2-13; Code 1981, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-62. - Control and direction of clerk, etc. 
    The clerk of the city council and other officers and employees of the city council shall be under the direction of the chair during sessions of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-16; Code 1981, § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-63. - Department heads, etc. 
    The head of any department or any officer or employee of the city, when requested by the city manager, shall attend any regular, adjourned or special meeting and confer with the city council on all matters relating to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-8; Code 1981, § 2-36) 
Sec. 2-64. - Decorum and order. 
    The presiding officer of the city council shall preserve decorum and decide on questions of order, subject to appeal to the city council. If a member transgresses the provisions of this article, the presiding officer shall call him to order. 
(Code 1967, § 2-19; Code 1981, § 2-37) 
Sec. 2-65. - Penalty for disorderly behavior or absence. 
    The city council may fine its members in an amount not exceeding $100.00 for disorderly behavior and for absence without just cause from any regular or special meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-20; Code 1981, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-66. - Unsigned communications. 
    Unsigned or anonymous communications shall not be introduced in council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-42; Code 1981, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-67. - Leaving council chamber. 
    No member of the city council shall leave the city council chamber while in regular meeting without permission from the presiding officer. 
(Code 1967, § 2-27; Code 1981, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-68. - Admission of non-city officers within bar. 
    No person except members of the city council and the officers named in this article and persons invited by the presiding officer of the city council or by the vote of council shall be admitted within the bar of the city council chamber. 
(Code 1967, § 2-15; Code 1981, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-69. - Addressing council. 
    Persons other than members of the city council and city officers shall not be permitted to address the city council, except upon introduction by the presiding officer. 
(Code 1967, § 2-22; Code 1981, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-70. - Speaking to councilmember. 
    If any person, other than a city officer desires to speak to a member of council while council is in session, the person shall first be recognized by the presiding officer and if the member is agreeable to the request, the member shall leave his seat and retire to the rear of the city council chamber or elsewhere until the conversation is finished. 
(Code 1967, § 2-28; Code 1981, § 2-43) 
Sec. 2-71. - Executive sessions. 
    No executive session of the city council shall be held except in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1967, § 2-11; Code 1981, § 2-44) 
State Law reference- Virginia Freedom of Information Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3700 et seq.; closed meetings authorized, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3711. 
Secs. 2-72-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMITTEES 

Sec. 2-101. - Appointment. 
    The mayor may appoint from time to time such special or select committees, consisting of at least one councilmember, and shall designate the chair thereof, as in his discretion he deems desirable or as may be desired by the city council, to expedite the handling of the business and affairs of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-44; Code 1981, § 2-51) 
Sec. 2-102. - Meetings. 
    It shall be the duty of the chair of each special committee to give notice as provided in Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3707 of the time and place of meeting of such committee and to all members of the city council, the clerk of the city council, the city manager and all other persons known to be interested, in favor of or opposed to the particular matters proposed to be considered. 
(Code 1967, § 2-46; Code 1981, § 2-52) 
State Law reference- Public notice of meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3707. 
Sec. 2-103. - Employees. 
    No committee of the city council shall have the power of employing any person for, or on behalf of, the city, or incur any expense, unless specially authorized by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-50; Code 1981, § 2-53) 
Sec. 2-104. - Secretary. 
    The clerk of the city council shall act as secretary to special committees and shall keep a record of the attendance and business transacted at their meetings. 
(Code 1967, § 2-49; Code 1981, § 2-54) 
Sec. 2-105. - Relief from further consideration. 
    At a city council meeting, upon motion, the city council may, by a majority vote relieve a special committee of further consideration of a matter referred to it. 
(Code 1967, § 2-48; Code 1981, § 2-55) 
Sec. 2-106. - Reports. 
    Reports of special committees shall be in writing, agreed to in committee assembled and shall not be presented unless signed by a majority of the committee. Copies of the report shall be available to each member. Documents referred to the committee shall be returned with the report. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the introduction of minority reports. 
(Code 1967, § 2-47; Code 1981, § 2-56) 
Secs. 2-107-2-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RULES OF PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Council meetings and rules of procedure, § 3.9. 

Sec. 2-126. - Order of business. 
    Unless the city council, by a vote of at least two-thirds of the members present, shall suspend the rules and change the order, the business of all regular meetings of the city council shall be transacted in the following order: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Pledge of Allegiance. 
(3)  Approval of minutes of previous meeting. 
(4)  Recognition/communication from visitors. 
(5)  Report of: 
a.  Mayor. 
b.  City manager. 
c.  City attorney. 
(6)  Old business. 
(7)  New business. 
(Code 1967, § 2-17; Code 1981, § 2-66) 
Sec. 2-127. - Opening of meetings. 
    The mayor shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the city council to meet and shall immediately call the members to order. 
(Code 1967, § 2-12; Code 1981, § 2-67) 
Sec. 2-128. - Reading and approval of minutes. 
    At each regular meeting of the city council, the minutes of the preceding regular meeting and any special meeting shall be presented for approval. If no objection is made to the minutes, the minutes shall be approved. 
(Code 1967, § 2-18; Code 1981, § 2-68) 
Sec. 2-129. - Election of officers. 
    A majority of all members elected to the city council shall be required to elect a vice-mayor, clerk of the city council, city manager and the city attorney. 
(Code 1967, § 2-9; Code 1981, § 2-69) 
Sec. 2-130. - Parliamentary guide. 
    At a meeting of the city council, in the absence of a rule to govern a point or procedure, reference shall be had to Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1967, § 2-45; Code 1981, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-131. - Personal privilege. 
    The right of a member to address the city council on a question of personal privilege shall be limited to cases in which his integrity, character or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned. 
(Code 1967, § 2-23; Code 1981, § 2-72) 
Sec. 2-132. - Continuance. 
    Any session of the city council may be continued or adjourned from day to day, or for more than one day, but no continuance or adjournment shall be for a longer period than until the next regular meeting thereafter. 
(Code 1967, § 2-6; Code 1981, § 2-73) 
Secs. 2-133-2-162. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MOTIONS 

Sec. 2-163. - Statement; writing. 
    When a motion is made and seconded at a meeting of the city council, it shall be stated by the chair before debate and any member may demand that it be put in writing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-34; Code 1981, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-164. - Withdrawal. 
    A motion may not be withdrawn by the mover without the consent of the member seconding it and the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-34; Code 1981, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-165. - When a question is before council. 
(a)  At a city council meeting, when a question is before the city council, no motion shall be entertained except: 
(1)  To adjourn; 
(2)  To lay on the table; 
(3)  For the previous question; 
(4)  To postpone to a certain day; 
(5)  To refer; 
(6)  To amend; 
(7)  To postpone indefinitely. 
(b)  These motions shall have precedence in the order indicated. 
(c)  Any such motion, except a motion to amend, shall be put to a vote without debate. 
(Code 1967, § 2-35; Code 1981, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-166. - Amendments to amendments. 
    At a city council meeting, a motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be introduced. An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but an amendment relating to a different matter shall not be in order. 
(Code 1967, § 2-39; Code 1981, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-167. - To lay on the table. 
    At a city council meeting, a motion to lay on the table shall preclude all amendments or debate of the subject under consideration. If such motion shall prevail, the consideration of the subject may be resumed only upon motion of a member of the city council voting with the majority and with the consent of two-thirds of the members present and voting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-36; Code 1981, § 2-85) 
Sec. 2-168. - To postpone. 
    At a city council meeting, all motions to postpone, except motions to postpone indefinitely, may be amended as to time and if a motion to postpone indefinitely is carried, the principal question shall be declared lost. 
(Code 1967, § 2-40; Code 1981, § 2-86) 
Sec. 2-169. - Subjects of debate. 
    When recognized by the chair, a member of the city council shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoid personalities and refrain from impugning the motives of any other member's argument or vote. 
(Code 1967, § 2-21; Code 1981, § 2-87) 
Sec. 2-170. - Limitation of debate. 
    No member of the city council shall be allowed to speak more than once upon any one subject until every other member choosing to speak thereon shall have spoken, and no such member shall speak more than twice upon any one subject, nor for a longer time than ten minutes without permission of council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-25; Code 1981, § 2-88) 
Sec. 2-171. - Division of question. 
    At a city council meeting, if a question contains two or more divisible propositions, the presiding officer may, and upon request of a member shall, divide the same. 
(Code 1967, § 2-37; Code 1981, § 2-89) 
Sec. 2-172. - Tie vote. 
    At a meeting of the city council, in case of a tie in votes on any proposal, the proposal shall be considered lost. 
(Code 1967, § 2-43; Code 1981, § 2-90) 
Sec. 2-173. - Reconsideration. 
    At a meeting of the city council, any member of the city council who voted with the majority may move a reconsideration of any action on the same for the next succeeding meeting; provided, however, that a resolution authorizing or relating to any contract may be reconsidered at any time before the final execution thereof. A motion to reconsider shall require the same number of votes as is required to adopt an ordinance or resolution. After a motion for reconsideration has once been acted on, no other motion for a reconsideration thereof shall be made without unanimous consent. 
(Code 1967, § 2-41; Code 1981, § 2-91) 
Sec. 2-174. - Appeal from ruling of chair. 
    Any member of the city council may appeal to the city council from a ruling of the presiding officer. If the appeal is seconded, the member making the appeal may briefly state his reason for the same, and the presiding officer may briefly explain his ruling; but there shall be no debate on the appeal and no other member shall participate in the discussion. The presiding officer shall then put the question, "Shall the decision of the chair be sustained?" and, if a majority of the members present vote "aye," the ruling of the chair is sustained; otherwise, it is overruled. 
(Code 1967, § 2-24; Code 1981, § 2-92) 
Secs. 2-175-2-201. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - ORDINANCES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Ordinances, §§ 3.901-3.905. 

Sec. 2-202. - Filing with clerk. 
    Every ordinance, resolution and document to come before the city council for consideration shall be filed with the clerk of the city council before noon of the day on which the city council meets. 
(Code 1967, § 2-29; Code 1981, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-203. - Titles prepared. 
    It shall be the duty of the clerk of the city council to have ready for delivery by 3:00 p.m. of the preceding Tuesday before the city council meeting on Thursday, a brief statement setting forth a full descriptive title of all ordinances, resolutions and documents to come before the city council on Thursday. 
(Code 1967, § 2-30; Code 1981, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-204. - Copies. 
    The clerk of the city council shall prepare copies of all proposed ordinances for distribution to all city councilmembers at the meeting at which the ordinance is to be introduced. Whenever any city councilmember is absent from such meeting, the clerk shall arrange to have copies delivered to them. 
(Code 1967, § 2-31; Code 1981, § 2-103) 
Sec. 2-205. - Introduction. 
    Ordinances shall be introduced to the city council by the mayor, and shall be in written form. 
(Code 1967, § 2-32; Code 1981, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-206. - First reading. 
    The first reading of an ordinance shall be for information. If there are objections to it, the question shall be: "Shall the proposal be rejected?" 
(Code 1967, § 2-33; Code 1981, § 2-105) 
Sec. 2-207. - Amendment. 
    At a city council meeting, it shall be in order to amend an ordinance at any time. If an ordinance, after its second reading, is amended, it shall be read as the first reading thereof and laid over for further and final consideration. 
(Code 1967, § 2-38; Code 1981, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-208. - Dissent or protest. 
    Any member of the city council shall have the right to express dissent from or protest against any ordinance or resolution of council and have the reason therefor entered upon the minutes. Such dissent or protest shall be filed in writing couched in respectful language, and presented to the city council not later than the next regular meeting following the date of passage of the ordinance or resolution objected to. 
(Code 1967, § 2-26; Code 1981, § 2-107) 
Secs. 2-209-2-239. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-260. - Pay increases.

DIVISION 2. - COURT COSTS 

Sec. 2-438. - Costs. 
    In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120, as amended, a fee of $10.00 shall be assessed as part of the fees taxed as costs in each criminal or traffic case in the circuit or the district court for the city, in which the defendant is convicted for violation of any statute or ordinance. 
(Ord. of 1-23-1997; Ord. of 7-24-1997; Ord. of 5-10-2007) 
State Law reference- Authority to assess costs courthouse or jail facilities, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281; authority to levy fee for court facilities, Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120. 
Sec. 2-439. - Fees for the construction, renovation or maintenance of the courthouse. 
    A fee of $3.00 shall be assessed as part of the costs in each civil, criminal or traffic case to be used solely for the construction, renovation or maintenance of the courthouse. The fee shall not be assessed in any civil action if the amount in controversy is $500.00 or less. The additional fee may only be assessed by localities that, on or after January 1, 2009, operated a courthouse not in compliance with the current safety and security guidelines contained in the Virginia Courthouse Facility guidelines and the courthouse cannot be feasibly renovated to correct the noncompliance. 
(Ord. of 6-18-2009) 
State Law reference- Additional assessment for courthouse, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281D. 
Sec. 2-440. - Fees. 
    In all criminal convictions resulting in prosecution in the courts of the city, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 53.1-131.1, there shall be assessed as costs related to the conviction and disposition thereof made as follows: 
(1)  The heretofore provided assessments made by the courts to defray costs of weekend and nonconsecutive days in jail are to be remitted to the treasurer of the city. This is authorized pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 53.1-131.1. 
(2)  A sheriff's processing fee ("jail admission fee") shall be imposed in an amount of $25.00 on any individual admitted to jail following conviction. This jail admission fee is to be placed into an account, Code 234. 
(3)  An assessment for courthouse and courtroom security personnel shall be made pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120. The assessment shall be in the amount of $5.00 in each criminal or traffic conviction in the district or circuit court. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court and remitted to the local treasurer and held by the treasurer subject to appropriation by the city council to the sheriff's office for the funding of courthouse security personnel. 
(Ord. of 8-8-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy fee to defray costs for weekend and nonconsecutive day confinement, Code of Virginia, § 53.1-131.1. 
Sec. 2-441. - Additional fee for criminal and traffic cases. 
    An additional $5.00 fee shall be made a part of the cost for each criminal and/or traffic case within the district or circuit court cases for the City of Buena Vista and that in accordance with the state law, this fee shall be collected by the clerks of the court and remitted to the treasurer for the City of Buena Vista to use as directed by city council to fund the software, hardware and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
(Ord. No. 16-07, 10-6-2016) 
Secs. 2-442-2-463. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARBAGE, WATER AND SEWER FEE RELIEF PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-464. - Purpose. 
    Certain elderly and disabled residents of the city, due to their financial status are excessively burdened with the garbage, water and sewer fees, and therefore in order to promote the health and welfare of all citizens of the city, the city hereby adopts the garbage, water and sewer fee relief program set forth in this article. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-465. - Individuals eligible to apply for fee exemption. 
    In order to qualify you must either: 
(1)  Qualify under the real estate relief for the elderly and disabled in accordance with division 2 of article II of chapter 16; 
(2)  Are not less than 65 years of age; or 
(3)  A person permanently and totally disabled. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-466. - Financial qualifications. 
    In order to qualify: 
(1)  An individual and his or her relatives living in the same dwelling shall not have a combined total income (from all sources) during the immediately preceding calendar year exceeding $25,000.00; and 
(2)  The net combined financial worth of the individual applying, and his or her spouse, as of December 31 of the immediately preceding calendar year shall not exceed $65,000.00. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-467. - Fee relief. 
    The fee relief granted shall be based on the following gross income scale: 
Income Level 
(in dollars) Reduction 
(in percent) 0.00-6,000.00 80 6,001.00-12,000.00 60 12,001.00-18,000.00 40 18,001.00-25,000.00 20  
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-468. - Disability. 
    Any person claiming exemption under disability shall provide a certification from the Social Security Administration, the Veteran's Affair or the Railroad Retirement Board, or if said person is not eligible for certification by any of these agencies, a sworn affidavit by two medical doctors who are either licensed to practice medicine in the Commonwealth or a military officer on active duty who practices medicine with the United States Armed Services, to the effect that the person is permanently and totally disabled as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3217, as amended, however a certification pursuant to 42 USC 423(d) by the Social Security Administration so long as the person remains eligible for such social security benefits shall be deemed to satisfy such definition in the aforesaid Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3217. The affidavit of at least one of the doctors shall be based upon a physical examination of the person by such doctor. The affidavit of one of the doctors may be based upon medical information contained in the records of the Civil Service Commission, which is relevant to the standard for determining permanent and total disability as defined in the aforesaid Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3217. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-469. - Administration of program. 
    This exemption shall be administered by the commissioner of revenue for the city. The commissioner of revenue is hereby authorized and empowered to make such inquiry of persons seeking such exemption in conformance with the provisions of this article, including the requiring of answering under oath, as may be reasonably necessary to determine qualifications for exemptions as specified by this article. The commissioner of revenue may require the production of certified income tax returns and appraisal reports to establish income and/or financial worth. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-470. - Claims. 
(a)  Annually, and not later than November 15 of each year, the person or persons claiming this exemption must file a garbage, water/sewer fee relief application with the commissioner of revenue for the city. 
(b)  The application shall set forth, in a manner prescribed by the commissioner of revenue, the names of the related persons occupying the applicant's dwelling, their gross combined income and a total combined net worth of the applicant and his or her spouse. The application shall also state whether the person or persons claiming the exemption claim the age or disability exemption or qualify under the real estate relief provisions of division 2 of article II of chapter 16. 
(c)  If after an audit or investigation, the commissioner of revenue determines the persons are qualified for this exemption, it shall be so certified to the utility department, who shall deduct the amount of exemption from the claimant's garbage, water and sewer bill. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-471. - Change in status. 
    Changes in respect to income, financial worth, or other factors occurring during the taxable year for which the application is filed and having the effect of exceeding or violating the limitations and conditions provided for in this article shall nullify any relief granted for the garbage, water/sewer fees for the then-current year and the year immediately following. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-472. - Violations. 
    Any person or persons falsely claiming an exemption under this article shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Sec. 2-473. - Application. 
    The following is an application form for the fee relief program: 
Garbage, Water and Sewer Fee Relief Application No.  ____________  
The Buena Vista City Council, effective January 1, 2005, has enacted an ordinance for the exemption of fees for certain individuals not less than 65 years of age or of a person permanently and totally disabled. The financial qualifications are as follows: 
1. In order to qualify, an individual and his or her relatives living in the same dwelling shall not have a total combined income (from all sources) during the immediately preceding calendar year exceeding $25,000.00. 2. The net combined financial worth of the individual applying and his or her spouse as of December 31 of the immediately preceding calendar year shall not exceed $65,000.00.  
The fee relief granted shall be based on the following income level: 
Name of applicant _____Address _____ 
I (we), having attained the age of 65 years or are permanently and totally disabled, I (we) live at the address noted above as my (our) sole residence, do apply for the fee relief above described and make oath that my (our) household income and financial worth is not in excess of the limitations above provided. 
Applicant _____By  ____________ Date of Birth _____Telephone _____Account Number _____ 
Applicant qualifies for the following percentage fee relief  ____________ 
_____
Commissioner of the Revenue Date  ____________  
(Ord. of 9-9-2004) 
Secs. 2-474-2-499. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC-PRIVATE EDUCATION FACILITIES INFRASTRUCTURE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Public-private education facilities and infrastructure act, Code of Virginia, § 56-575.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-500. - Introduction. 
(a)  The Public-Private Education Facilities and Infrastructure Act of 2002, Code of Virginia, §§ 56-575.1 to 56-575.16 as amended, (the "PPEA"), grants a public entity the authority to create public-private partnerships for the development of a wide range of projects for public use ("qualifying projects") if the public entity determines that there is a need for a project and that private involvement may provide the project to the public in a timely or cost-effective fashion. The term "public entity" as defined in Code of Virginia, § 56-575.1 of the PPEA includes, inter alia, any political subdivision of the commonwealth. 
(b)  In order for a project to come under the PPEA, it must meet the definition of the term "qualifying project," which is broadly defined in the PPEA to include public buildings and facilities of all types. 
(c)  Code of Virginia, § 56-575.3:1 provides that a responsible public entity ("RPE"), one which has the power to develop or operate a qualifying project, may not consider any proposal by a private entity for approval of the qualifying project pursuant to the PPEA until the RPE has adopted and made publicly available, guidelines that are sufficient to enable the RPE to comply with the PPEA. Accordingly, these guidelines (the "guidelines") are hereby adopted by the city council as the governing body of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-18-2008, § I) 
Sec. 2-501. - General provisions. 
(a)  Proposals. 
(1)  Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 56-575.4, a proposal to provide a qualifying project to a RPE may be either solicited from private entities by the public entity (solicited bid/proposal) or delivered to the public entity by a private entity on an unsolicited basis (unsolicited proposal). In either case, any such proposal shall be clearly identified as a PPEA proposal. 
(2)  The requirements for any particular solicited bid/proposal shall be as specified in the solicitation by the city for that particular proposal and shall be consistent with all applicable provisions of the PPEA. 
(3)  Any unsolicited proposal shall be submitted to the city by delivering six complete copies, together with the required initial review fee as provided in section 2-503(4), to the Office of City Manager, 2039 Sycamore Avenue, Buena Vista, Virginia 24416. Other requirements for an unsolicited proposal are set forth in section 2-503. A working group may be designated by city council to review and evaluate all unsolicited proposals. 
(4)  The city may require that any proposal be clarified. Such clarification may include but is not limited to submission of additional documentation, responses to specific questions, and interviews with potential project participants. 
(b)  Affected local jurisdictions. 
(1)  The term "affected local jurisdiction" includes any county, city or town in which all or a portion of a qualifying project is located. 
(2)  Any private entity submitting a solicited bid/proposal or an unsolicited proposal to the city as the RPE for a qualifying project must provide any other affected local jurisdiction with a copy of the proposal by certified mail, express delivery, or hand delivery within five business days of submission of the proposal to the city. Each affected local jurisdiction that is not a RPE for the respective qualifying project shall, within 60 days from receipt of the copy of the proposal, submit written comments to the RPE and indicate whether the proposed qualifying project is compatible with the affected jurisdiction's local comprehensive plan, local infrastructure development plans, capital improvements budget, or other government spending plan. Comments received within the 60-day period shall be given consideration by the RPE, prior to entering into a comprehensive agreement pursuant to the PPEA with the private entity. However, the city may begin or continue its evaluation of any such proposal during the 60-day period for the receipt of comments from affected local jurisdictions. 
(c)  State Freedom of Information Act. 
(1)  Any confidential and proprietary information provided to a RPE by a private entity pursuant to the PPEA shall be subject to disclosure under the state Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA") except as provided by Code of Virginia, § 56-575.4(G) of the PPEA. 
(2)  In order to prevent the release of any confidential and proprietary information that otherwise could be held in confidence pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 56-575.4(G), the private entity submitting the information must: 
a.  Invoke the exclusion from FOIA when the data or materials are submitted to the city or before such submission; 
b.  Identify the data and materials for which protection from disclosure is sought; and 
c.  State why the exclusion from disclosure is necessary. 
A private entity may request and receive a written determination from the city as to the anticipated scope of protection prior to submitting the proposal. The city is authorized and obligated to protect only confidential proprietary information, and thus will not protect any portion of a proposal from disclosure if the entire proposal has been designated confidential by the private entity without reasonably differentiating between the proprietary and nonproprietary information contained therein. 
(3)  Upon receipt of a request from a private entity that designated portions of a proposal be protected from disclosure as confidential and proprietary, the city will determine whether such protection is appropriate under applicable law and, if appropriate, the scope of such appropriate protection, and shall communicate its determination to the private entity. If the determination regarding protection or the scope thereof differs from the private entity's request, then the city will accord the private entity a reasonable opportunity to clarify and justify its request. Upon a final determination by the city to accord less protection than requested by the private entity, the private entity will be given an opportunity to withdraw its proposal. A proposal so withdrawn will be treated in the same manner as a proposal not accepted for publication and conceptual-phase consideration as provided in section 2-503(1)a. 
(d)  Use of public funds. State constitutional and statutory requirements as they apply to appropriation and expenditure of public funds apply to any interim or comprehensive agreement entered into under the PPEA. Accordingly, the processes and procedural requirements associated with the expenditure or obligation of public funds shall be incorporated into planning for any PPEA project or projects. 
(e)  Applicability of other laws. Nothing in the PPEA shall affect the duty of the city to comply with all other applicable law not in conflict with the PPEA. The applicability of the Virginia Public Procurement Act (the "VPPA") is as set forth in the PPEA. 
(Ord. of 12-18-2008, § II) 
Sec. 2-502. - Solicited bid/proposals. 
(a)  The procedures applicable to any particular solicited bid/proposal should specify, but not necessarily be limited to, information and documents that must accompany the solicited bid/proposal and the factors that will be used to evaluate the submitted solicited bid/proposal. All procedures shall be consistent with the requirements of the PPEA and any other applicable law. All such solicitations shall be by issuance of a written invitation to bid (IFB) or request for proposal (RFP) within the meaning of those terms as used in the city's procedure for procurement.
