(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without authority of law, to go upon or remain upon the land constituting the Glen Maury Park owned by the city after having been forbidden to do so, either orally or in writing, by the city manager or his duly authorized agent, or after having been forbidden to do so by a sign or signs posted upon said property or its buildings. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to duly registered campers who have not had their registration cancelled. 
(c)  The prerogative to forbid a person from entering or going upon the property of Glen Maury Park shall rest with the park director, and anyone aggrieved by his decision shall have the right of appeal to the circuit court of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 17-2; Ord. No. 76-26, 8-12-1976) 
Chapter 26 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning, subdivision, etc., article 7. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt planning and zoning regulations, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2200; authority for council to give notice by direct mail of planning and zoning matters, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2205; planning, subdivision of land and zoning generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2200 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Planning and zoning, article 7. 
State Law reference- Local planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210 et seq. 

Sec. 26-19. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a planning commission of the city. Such commission shall bear the title of, and shall be known as, the city planning commission. Such creation is pursuant to the Charter of the city and the applicable state law. 
(Code 1967, § 19-1; Code 1981, § 20-16) 
State Law reference- Duty of council to create planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210. 
Sec. 26-20. - Composition. 
    In accordance with the Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212, the city planning commission shall consist of nine members, including the city manager, who shall be an ex officio member of the planning commission. Such members of the planning commission shall be residents of the city and at least half the members shall be freeholders qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development. 
(Code 1967, § 19-2; Code 1981, § 20-17; Ord. of 2-28-1980) 
State Law reference- Qualifications, appointment, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 26-21. - Appointment; term. 
    The members of the planning commission shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve for terms in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
(Code 1967, § 19-3; Code 1981, § 20-18) 
State Law reference- Members to serve staggered terms of four years, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 26-22. - Compensation. 
    The members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation by reason of the performance of the duties as a member of such commission. 
(Code 1967, § 19-5; Code 1981, § 20-19) 
State Law reference- Compensation, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 26-23. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning commission shall have all of the powers and duties conferred upon such planning commission by the general laws of the state and by the provisions of the Charter. 
(Code 1967, § 19-8; Code 1981, § 20-20) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning, etc., art. 7. 
State Law reference- Duties of planning commissions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2221. 
Sec. 26-24. - Regular meetings; rules; records. 
    The planning commission shall hold at least one regular meeting during each month and shall adopt rules and regulations for the transaction of its business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1967, § 19-6; Code 1981, § 20-21) 
State Law reference- Planning commission to establish time for meetings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2214. 
Sec. 26-25. - Chair. 
    The members of the planning commission shall, at the regular meeting of such commission held during the month of September of each year, elect one of the members of such commission as chair of the planning commission for a term of office of one year, and the chair shall be eligible for reelection upon the termination of his term of office. 
(Code 1967, § 19-7; Code 1981, § 20-22) 
State Law reference- Officers, employees, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2217. 
Sec. 26-26. - Reappointment of members. 
    A member of the planning commission shall be eligible for reappointment upon the termination of his term of office as a member of the planning commission. 
(Code 1967, § 19-4; Code 1981, § 20-23) 
State Law reference- Appointments, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Chapter 28 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require property owners to remove garbage and refuse and city's right to operate a garbage and refuse collection and disposal service, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-901, 15.2-927; authority of city to contract for and regulate garbage and refuse pickup and disposal services, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-930; solid and hazardous waste management, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-177 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Automobile bodies. 
    No person shall dump or deposit any automobile bodies or parts of automobile bodies in or upon the county landfill. 
(Code 1967, § 24-1; Code 1981, § 24-2) 
Secs. 28-2-28-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION, ETC., BY CITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-21. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall be construed to apply to commercial and residential premises. 
(Code 1967, § 24-3; Code 1981, § 24-16) 
Sec. 28-22. - Garbage containers-Liquids. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any liquid in any garbage or trash container. 
(Code 1967, § 24-8; Code 1981, § 24-20) 
Sec. 28-23. - Same-Injuring. 
    When a garbage container is placed on the outside of commercial or residential premises, it shall be unlawful for any person to throw such garbage container on the street or sidewalk or to injure it in any way so as to make it leak or bend it, or its cover, so as to prevent such garbage container from being tightly covered. 
(Code 1967, § 24-7; Code 1981, § 24-22) 
Sec. 28-24. - Fees and rates. 
    The sold waste fees and charges are on file in the city offices. 
(Code 1967, § 24-8.1; Code 1981, § 24-23; Ord. No. 75-07, 6-12-1975; Ord. of 7-10-1980; Ord. of 5-30-1985; Ord. of 5-26-1989; Ord. of 5-31-1990; Ord. of 4-13-1995; Ord. of 5-7-1998) 
Sec. 28-25. - Nonresident's use of solid waste containers. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nonresident means any individual, person, corporation, partnership or firm not having a place of abode or business licensed by the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any nonresident to place any material or waste of any type in or about the solid waste containers provided by the city. 
(c)  Any individual, person, firm, corporation, partnership or any other legal entity violating any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction therefor the first offense shall be punished by a fine not less than the sum of $25.00 or more than $100.00; upon the second and all subsequent offenses which result in a conviction, punishment shall be a fine not less than the sum of $100.00 nor more than $500.00 and by confinement in jail not to exceed the term of 30 days, either or both. 
(Code 1981, § 24-24; Ord. of 1-23-1992) 
Secs. 28-26-28-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL PREMISES 

Sec. 28-54. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this division shall be construed to apply to residential premises only. 
(Code 1967, § 24-9; Code 1981, § 24-31) 
Sec. 28-55. - Container location; entry by collector. 
    All containers containing garbage or refuse to be hauled away shall be so placed or located that they can be easily and conveniently reached by the persons hauling the garbage or refuse away. Such person shall not be required to enter any building for removal of any garbage or refuse. If any person connected with the garbage or trash removal services shall enter any building in connection with such work, he shall do so only on request and the city shall not be liable because of or on account of any claim made for any injury or damage caused by such person entering such building. 
(Code 1967, § 24-10; Code 1981, § 24-32) 
Sec. 28-56. - Containers set out for collection. 
    All containers containing garbage, ashes or refuse intended for collection by the city or by a contractor with the city shall be set out as provided in this article not earlier than 5:30 p.m. of the day preceding collection. 
(Code 1967, § 24-13; Code 1981, § 24-33) 
Sec. 28-57. - Removal of containers following collection. 
    All containers for garbage, ashes or refuse set out for collection by the city or by a contractor with the city shall be removed as promptly as possible following collection of the garbage, ashes or refuse. 
(Code 1967, § 24-14; Code 1981, § 24-34) 
Sec. 28-58. - Trash and other containers. 
    No bulk trash, refuse, tree limbs, shrubbery, leaves and other similar matter shall be collected without additional charge, unless such matter can be and is placed in a suitable container. 
(Code 1967, § 24-11; Code 1981, § 24-35) 
Sec. 28-59. - Limbs and cuttings. 
    Limbs and cuttings shall be cut in five-foot lengths and tied in bundles not exceeding 11/2 feet in diameter and placed by the garbage container on regular collection days. 
(Code 1967, § 24-12; Code 1981, § 24-36) 
Chapter 30 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power relating to public works and properties, § 2.3; authority to regulate activities in streets, § 2.304. 
State Law reference- General authority of city relative to streets and sidewalks, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2000 et seq., 15.2-2100 et seq.; alteration and vacation of public rights-of-way, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2006-15.2-2008; street obstructions and encroachments, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2009-15.2-2012; temporary closing of street, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2013, 15.2-2014; use of streets, permits, etc., Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2015-15.2-2018; naming of streets, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2019; assessments for local improvements, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2400 et seq.; local government authority over highways, etc., Code of Virginia, § 33.1-224 et seq.; laying of pipes in streets, Code of Virginia, § 56-257 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Authority of city manager. 
    The city manager shall have authority to prescribe regulations for work done on city streets by the city forces. 
(Code 1967, § 27-2; Code 1981, § 25-1) 
Sec. 30-2. - Acceptance of streets for care and maintenance. 
(a)  No street shall be accepted for care and maintenance by the city unless such new street has been graded and surfaced as provided in this chapter and dedicated by the recording of a plat drawn to scale showing such street, in the office of the clerk of the circuit court of the city, at the expense of the owner of the property, and no such acceptance shall take place until the plat of the street has been accepted and approved by the city council. 
(b)  Before new streets can be accepted by the city for care and maintenance, such streets must meet the requirements of the state department of highways and transportation. 
(Code 1967, § 27-1; Code 1981, § 25-2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Cellar doors or gratings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or construct or cause to be constructed any structure or obstruction in or upon any paved sidewalk within the city, unless prior approval is granted by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 27-5; Code 1981, § 25-3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Open cellar ways, areaways, etc., guarded. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any cellar way, areaway or other place of like character opening on or in a public sidewalk in the city to remain open unless properly guarded by bars or otherwise. 
(Code 1967, § 27-7; Code 1981, § 25-4) 
Sec. 30-5. - Gates and doors generally. 
    Every gate or door built or constructed in any fence, garden or yard wall, upon or within two feet of the line of any public sidewalk on any street in the city, shall be hung so as to open inward. 
(Code 1967, § 27-6; Code 1981, § 25-5) 
Sec. 30-6. - Permit to construct entrance to property on street. 
(a)  Any landowner desiring to construct a driveway, steps, curb cut or other entrance to his property which would result in construction on city streets or avenues shall first make application for and receive a permit from the city manager or designated agent authorizing the construction of any such entrance. The application shall contain information as prescribed by the city manager or his agent. The permit issued shall set forth the specifications for the proposed construction and the landowner shall comply with these specifications. 
(b)  Prior to issuance of such a permit to any landowner, the landowner shall first execute a hold harmless agreement with the city, agreeing to be financially responsible for any damage done to city or public utility installations and any cost which the city might be caused to expend as a result of the failure of the landowner to comply with the requirements of the permit issued. 
(Code 1967, § 27-14.1; Code 1981, § 25-6) 
Sec. 30-7. - Merchandise, boxes, crates, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit to remain upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks adjoining his premises any merchandise, boxes, crates or other things that will cause the streets, alleys or sidewalks to be obstructed. However, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the display of merchandise during the hours a person is open for business; provided that the display of such merchandise does not occupy more than one-half of the width of the sidewalk immediately adjacent to such business and does not unreasonably interfere with the orderly movement of pedestrians. Merchandise left on the sidewalks during nonbusiness hours shall be deemed to be on the sidewalk for purposes of storage and not display and in violation of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 27-8; Code 1981, § 25-7) 
Sec. 30-8. - Opening car doors. 
    No person shall open a car door so as to render dangerous the use of public streets or so as to obstruct traffic. 
(Code 1967, § 27-6.1; Code 1981, § 25-8) 
Sec. 30-9. - Removal of ground, dirt, etc., from street or alley. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up or carry away from any street or alley, within the city, any ground, dirt or stone without the written permission of the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-9; Code 1981, § 25-9) 
Sec. 30-10. - Building materials. 
    No person shall place building materials upon the street, sidewalk or alley for use in connection with construction work, unless he shall have first obtained a permit from the city manager to do so and unless he shall place such materials in the space assigned and in the manner directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-13; Code 1981, § 25-10) 
Sec. 30-11. - Throwing or depositing garbage, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw paper, garbage, liquid wastes, refuse, offal or other obnoxious or unsightly matter into or upon any street or public place of the city, or to permit or suffer the same to be done by any person in his employment, or to throw, place, drop or cause to be put, any coal, ashes, dirt or filth of any kind or any lumber, wood, stone or other obstruction into or upon any street or public place in the city. This section shall not be construed to apply to building material placed on the street, sidewalk or alley pursuant to section 30-10. 
(Code 1967, § 27-12; Code 1981, § 25-11) 
State Law reference- Litter control, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1414 et seq. 
Sec. 30-12. - Projecting trees, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or occupying property abutting a street or sidewalk to allow any trees, plants or shrubs growing on such property to project from the property in such manner as to obstruct or interfere with the safe passage of vehicles or pedestrians. 
(Code 1967, § 27-14; Code 1981, § 25-12) 
Sec. 30-13. - Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks. 
    The tenant or occupant, and in case there shall be no tenant or occupant, the owner, or any person having the care of any building or lot of land abutting on any curbed or paved sidewalk shall, during the first eight hours of daylight following the time when snow or ice ceases to fall or form, cause the same to be removed from such curbed or paved sidewalk. 
(Code 1967, § 27-3; Code 1981, § 25-13) 
State Law reference- Removal of snow and ice, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1115, 15.2-2025. 
Sec. 30-14. - Removal of snow and ice to sidewalks or streets prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any tenant or occupant, the owner or any person having the care of any building or lot of land to remove snow from such building, lot or land by removing the snow to any sidewalk or street. 
(Code 1967, § 27-4; Code 1981, § 25-14) 
Sec. 30-15. - An obstruction within five feet of right-of way prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to remain on the streets or avenues or at any point within the public right-of-way of such streets and avenues which is closer than five feet from the edge of the paved portion of such street or avenue or the curbing adjoining such street or avenue, any temporary or permanent obstruction including, but not limited to, any nonmotor vehicle recreational equipment, basketball goals or similar personal property. 
(Ord. of 9-11-2003) 
Secs. 30-16-30-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS AND LOTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Numbering of buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2024. 

Sec. 30-34. - Plat book showing numbers. 
    For the purpose of facilitating correct numbering, as provided in this article, a plat book of all streets, avenues and public highways within the city showing the proper number of all lots or houses fronting upon all streets, avenues or highways shall be kept on file in the office of the city manager. These plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during the regular office hours of the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-30; Code 1981, § 25-31) 
Sec. 30-35. - Location of numbers. 
    The numbers installed pursuant to this article shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building so that the number can be seen plainly from the street. Whenever any building is situated more than 50 feet from the street line, the number of such building shall be conspicuously displayed at the street line, near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building and upon the gatepost, fence, tree, post or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the sidewalk. 
(Code 1967, § 27-29; Code 1981, § 25-32) 
Sec. 30-36. - System established. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system of numbering of buildings and lots fronting on all streets and public ways in the city. All buildings and lots shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 27-21; Code 1981, § 25-33) 
Sec. 30-37. - Base lines. 
(a)  First Street shall constitute the base line for the numbering of buildings and lots on streets running north and south. 
(b)  Magnolia Avenue and its extension along Lombardy Avenue shall constitute the base line for the numbering of buildings and lots on streets running east and west. 
(Code 1967, § 27-22; Code 1981, § 25-34) 
Sec. 30-38. - Streets not extending through to the base line street. 
    All buildings and lots on streets that do not extend through to the base line street shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street in question did extend to the base line street. 
(Code 1967, § 27-24; Code 1981, § 25-35) 
Sec. 30-39. - Diagonal streets. 
    All buildings and lots on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as north and south streets if the diagonal runs more from the north to the south and the same as east and west streets if the diagonal runs more from the east to the west. 
(Code 1967, § 27-23; Code 1981, § 25-36) 
Sec. 30-40. - Assignment of numbers within blocks. 
(a)  The numbering of buildings and lots on each street shall begin at the base line. The numbers within the first block shall be from 100 to 199 and the numbers in each succeeding block shall increase from the base line in units of 100, namely the first block shall be 100 to 199, the second block shall be 200 to 299, the third block shall be 300 to 399 and so forth. There shall be assigned 100 numbers to each block or square or space that would be one block or square, if streets each way were so extended as to intersect each other, and one number shall be assigned to each ten feet of frontage. In blocks or equivalent space longer than 500 feet which is not intersected by a street if extended, the total length of space divided by 50 shall be used to determine the feet of frontage assigned to each number. 
(b)  Where blocks of different lengths occur on opposite sides of a street, the numbers on both sides shall be assigned on the basis of the shorter blocks, unless the city manager shall otherwise determine. 
(c)  All lots and houses on the north and west side of all streets shall be numbered with odd numbers, each increase from the base line one number for each ten feet of frontage or fraction thereof, except as provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. Where any building has more than one door serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each door serving a separate occupant, provided, the building is ten feet or more in width and if the entrances are not that far apart, the consecutive number shall be marked fractional. Buildings fronting on two or more streets shall have a number assigned only to the main entrance, unless other entrances serve different occupants. 
(Code 1967, § 27-25; Code 1981, § 25-37) 
Sec. 30-41. - Assignment of numbers. 
    When any person applies for the assignment of a number, the city manager shall inform such person concerning the number belonging or embraced within the limits of the lot or property in question, as provided in this article. In case of doubt as to the proper number to be assigned to any lot or building, the city manager shall determine the number of such lot or building. 
(Code 1967, § 27-27; Code 1981, § 25-38) 
Sec. 30-42. - Designation of portion of building. 
    Where only one number can be assigned to any house or building and the owner, occupant or agent of such house or building desires distinctive numbers for the upper or lower portion of any such house or building or for any part of such house or building fronting on any street, such owner, occupant or agent shall use the suffix A, B, C, etc., as may be required. 
(Code 1967, § 27-26; Code 1981, § 25-39) 
Sec. 30-43. - Duty of property owner; size of numbers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner of buildings and lots to ascertain the correct number or numbers as designated from the city manager for the property in question and to immediately fasten or locate the number or numbers so assigned upon the building in question as provided by this article. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has obtained from the city manager the official number of the premises. 
(b)  Numbers installed pursuant to this article shall be procured and paid for by the owner of the property in question. The numbers used shall not be less than three inches in height. 
(Code 1967, § 27-28; Code 1981, § 25-40) 
Secs. 30-44-30-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate activities in streets, § 2.304. 
State Law reference- Alteration and vacation of public rights-of-way, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2006-15.2-2008; street obstructions and encroachments, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2009-15.2-2012; temporary closing of street, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2013, 15.2-2014; use of streets, permits, etc., Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2015-15.2-2018. 

Sec. 30-75. - Exception. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to work done by city forces under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-20; Code 1981, § 25-52) 
Sec. 30-76. - Permit required. 
    No person, unless specially authorized by the city council, shall take up or remove any portion of the surface of the sidewalk or street, or excavate in any public street of the city, without a written permit from the city manager, who shall not refuse such permit to any applicant except for cause, but in case of refusal the applicant may appeal to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 27-15; Code 1981, § 25-53) 
Sec. 30-77. - Deposits; acquiescence in provisions of article. 
(a)  Before a permit as required in this article is granted, the city manager may require a deposit sufficient to pay for resurfacing the street to be disturbed, the amount of such deposit to be determined by the city manager. 
(b)  Every person who shall make application for such a permit shall be deemed to have assented thereby to all the provisions and terms of this article, including the right of the city to collect the actual cost of replacing the pavement, sidewalk or street surface in the manner directed in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 27-16; Code 1981, § 25-54) 
Sec. 30-78. - Duty to prosecute work without delay. 
    It shall be the duty of every person to whom a permit, as required in this article, shall have been granted, to institute at once and prosecute without delay the work for which such permit was obtained, and promptly, on its completion, give written notice thereof to the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-17; Code 1981, § 25-55) 
Sec. 30-79. - Lights and barriers; damages. 
    Any person to whom a permit, as required in this article, is granted shall place guards or barriers around the excavation in question and shall protect it by warning lights at night, and shall be responsible for damages to persons or property caused by such excavations until taken in charge by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 27-19; Code 1981, § 25-56) 
Sec. 30-80. - Replacing surface. 
    No pavement, sidewalk or street surface shall be replaced, after being taken up, pursuant to a permit as required in this article, by any person except under the direction of the city manager. If the applicant fails to resurface the street disturbed, promptly and in a manner approved by the city manager, the city manager is authorized to cause such work to be done at the expense of the applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 27-18; Code 1981, § 25-57) 
Secs. 30-81-30-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CEMETERY 

Sec. 30-104. - Rates. 
    The following cemetery rates and charges are hereby established: 
(1)  Resident lot sale, $550.00 to $900.00. 
(2)  Nonresident lot sale, $1,100.00 to $1,200.00. 
(3)  Weekday grave opening, $400.00 to $750.00. 
(4)  Weekend grave opening, $550.00 to $1,000.00. 
(5)  Holiday grave opening, $650.00 to $1,000.00. 
(Ord. of 7-22-1999) 
Chapter 32 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to control, regulate, limit and restrict, as permitted by general law, the operation of motor vehicles, § 2.412. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100 et seq.; general authority of city to regulate traffic, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antique motor vehicle means every motor vehicle which was actually manufactured, or designated by the manufacturer as a model manufactured, in a calendar year not less than 25 years prior to January 1 of each calendar year and is owned solely as a collector's item, and is used for participation in club activities, exhibits, tours, parades and similar uses, but in no event used for general transportation, and which has been classified by the commissioner as an antique motor vehicle. 
    Bicycle means a device propelled solely by human power, upon which a person may ride either on or astride a regular seat attached thereto, having two or more wheels in tandem, including children's bicycles, except a toy vehicle intended for use by young children. For purposes of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-800 et seq., a bicycle shall be a vehicle while operated on the highway. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to a street or highway where 75 percent or more of the property contiguous to a street or highway, on either side of the street or highway, for a distance of 300 feet or more along the street or highway, is occupied by land and buildings actually in use and operation for business purposes. 
    Camping trailer means every vehicle which has collapsible sides and contains sleeping quarters, but may or may not contain bathing and cooking facilities, and is designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    Chauffeur means every person employed for the principal purpose of operating a motor vehicle and every person who drives a motor vehicle while in use as a public or common carrier of persons or property. 
    Commission means the state corporation commission. 
    Commissioner means the commissioner of the department of motor vehicles of this state. 
    Crosswalk means the part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the street or highway, measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway. The term "crosswalk" also means and includes any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Dealer means every person engaged in the business of buying, selling or exchanging motor vehicles, trailers and semitrailers in this city and who has an established place of business for such purpose in this city, at which place of business the books and records of such dealer are kept and at which a substantial part of the business of such dealer is conducted. 
    Department means the department of motor vehicles of this state. 
    Essential parts means all integral parts and body parts, the removal, alteration or substitution of which will tend to conceal the identity of a vehicle. 
    Farm tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm, agricultural or horticultural implement for drawing plows, mowing machines and other farm, agricultural or horticultural machinery and implements, including self-propelled mowers designed and used for mowing lawns. 
    Highway or street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way or place of whatever nature open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel in this city, including the streets, alleys and publicly maintained parking lots in the city, and for law enforcement purposes, the entire width between the boundary lines of all private roads or private streets which have been specifically designated "highways" by an ordinance adopted by the city council. 
    Intersection means: 
(1)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles travelling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
(2)  Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
(3)  For purposes only of authorizing installation of traffic control devices, every crossing of a highway or street at grade by a pedestrian crosswalk. 
    Mobile home means every vehicle not otherwise classified in this section which has noncollapsible sides, which contains sleeping quarters and may or may not contain bathing and cooking facilities, and every trailer not designed for the transportation of property but is used primarily for office space and is designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled or designed for self-propulsion. Any structure designed, used or maintained primarily to be loaded on or affixed to a motor vehicle to provide a mobile dwelling, sleeping place, office or commercial space shall be considered a part of a motor vehicle. Any device defined in this section as a "bicycle" shall be deemed not to be a motor vehicle. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground and any four-wheeled vehicle weighing less than 500 pounds and equipped with an engine of less than six horsepower, except any such vehicle as may be included within the term "farm tractor" as defined in this section. 
    Nonresident. 
(1)  The term "nonresident" means every person who is not domiciled in this state. 
(2)  The term "nonresident" does not mean: 
a.  Any foreign corporation which is authorized to do business in this state by the state corporation commission shall be deemed a resident of this state for the purpose of this chapter; provided, however, that in the case of corporations incorporated in this state but doing business without the state, only such principal place of business or branches located within this state shall be dealt with as residents of this state. 
b.  A person who becomes engaged in a gainful occupation in the state for a period exceeding 60 days shall be deemed a resident for the purposes of this chapter. 
c.  A person who has actually resided in this state for a period of six months, whether employed or not, or who has registered a motor vehicle, listing an address within this state in the application for registration, shall be deemed a resident for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a highway or who is exercising control over or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
    Owner means a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle or, in the event a vehicle is the subject to an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of a vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner for the purpose of this chapter, except that in all such instances when the rent paid by the lessee includes charges for services of any nature or when the lease does not provide that title shall pass to the lessee upon payment of the rent stipulated, the lessor shall be regarded as the owner of such vehicle and the vehicle shall be subject to such requirements of this chapter as are applicable to vehicles operated for compensation; provided, however, that a "truck lessor," as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, shall be regarded as the owner, and his vehicles shall be subject to such requirements of this chapter as are applicable to vehicles of private carriers. 
    Peace or police officer means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Pneumatic tires means all tires inflated with compressed air. 
    Private road or driveway means every way in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
    Reconstructed vehicle means every vehicle of a type required to be registered under state law, which is materially altered from its original construction by the removal, addition or substitution of essential parts, new or used. 
    Rescue vehicle means any vehicle designed or utilized for the principal purposes of supplying resuscitation or other emergency relief where human life is endangered. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to a street or highway, not comprising a business district, where 75 percent or more of the property contiguous to such street or highway, on either side of the street or highway, for a distance of 300 feet or more along the street or highway, is occupied by dwellings and land improved for dwelling purposes or by land or buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Road tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulder. A street or highway may include two or more roadways, if divided by a physical barrier or barriers or unpaved area. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    School bus means any motor vehicle, other than a station wagon, automobile, truck or commercial bus, which is: 
(1)  Designed and used primarily for the transportation of pupils to and from public, private or religious schools, or used for the transportation of the mentally or physically handicapped to and from a sheltered workshop; and 
(2)  Painted yellow and bears the words "School Bus" in black letters of a specified size on front and rear; and 
(3)  Is equipped with warning devices prescribed in Code of Virginia, § 46.1-1090. 
    Semitrailer means every vehicle of the trailer type so designed and used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of its own load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
    Shoulder means that part of a street or highway between the portion regularly travelled by vehicular traffic and the lateral curbline or ditch. 
    Solid rubber tire means every tire made of rubber other than a pneumatic tire. 
    Specially constructed vehicle means any vehicle which shall not have been originally constructed under a distinctive name, make, model or type by a generally recognized manufacturer of vehicles, and not a "reconstructed vehicle," as that term is defined in this section. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the department of state police. 
    Tractor truck means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the load and weight of the vehicle attached thereto. 
    Traffic infraction means a violation of law punishable as provided in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-113, which is neither a felony nor a misdemeanor. 
    Traffic lane or lane means that portion of a roadway designed or designated to accommodate the forward movement of a single line of vehicles. 
    Trailer means every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying property or passengers wholly on its own structure and for being drawn by a motor vehicle, including manufactured homes. 
    Truck means every motor vehicle designed to transport property on its own structure independent of any other vehicle and having a registered gross weight in excess of 7,500 pounds. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway. For the purposes of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-800 et seq., bicycles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, electric power-assisted bicycles, and mopeds shall be vehicles while operated on a highway. 
(Code 1967, § 16-2; Code 1981, § 13-1; Ord. of 6-8-2000; Ord. of 6-13-2002) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100. 
Sec. 32-2. - Compliance with chapter; general penalty for violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. Unless otherwise stated, such violations shall constitute traffic infractions punishable by a fine of not more than that provided for Class 4 misdemeanor under Code of Virginia, § 18.2-11. 
(Code 1967, § 16-31; Code 1981, § 13-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions applicable to violations of state traffic laws, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-113; maximum penalties for violation of traffic ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-113. 
Sec. 32-3. - Applicability of chapter to drivers, regardless of vehicle ownership. 
    The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles, regardless of ownership, subject to such specific exceptions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 16-4; Code 1981, § 13-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-801. 
Sec. 32-4. - Applicability of chapter to persons riding or driving animals. 
    Every person riding or driving an animal upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter and shall have all of the rights and all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions which, by their very nature, can have no application. 
(Code 1967, § 16-5; Code 1981, § 13-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-800. 
Sec. 32-5. - Exemptions for operators of emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The operator of any law enforcement vehicle operated by or under the direction of a federal, state or local law enforcement officer in the chase or apprehension of violators of the law or persons charged with or suspected of any such violation, or in response to an emergency call; any vehicle used for the purpose of fighting fire, including publicly owned state forest warden vehicles not to exceed 200 in number, when traveling in response to a fire alarm or emergency call; any vehicle owned by a political subdivision of the state for rescue purposes, when traveling in response to a fire alarm or an emergency call; or any ambulance or rescue or life-saving vehicle designed or utilized for the principal purposes of supplying resuscitation or emergency relief where human life is endangered, when such vehicle is being used in the performance of public services, and when such vehicle is operated under emergency conditions, may, without subjecting himself to criminal prosecution: 
(1)  Proceed past a red signal, light, stop sign or device indicating moving traffic shall stop, if the speed and movement of the vehicle are reduced and controlled so that it can pass a signal, light or devices with due regard to the safety of persons and property. 
(2)  Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Disregard regulations governing a direction of movement of vehicles turning in specified directions, so long as the operator does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Pass or overtake, with due regard to the safety of persons and property, another vehicle at any intersection. 
(5)  Pass or overtake, with due regard to the safety of persons and property, while in route to an emergency, other stopped or slow-moving vehicles, by going off the paved or main traveled portion of the roadway on the right. Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, vehicles exempted in this instance will not be required to sound a siren or any device to give automatically intermittent signals. 
(b)  The exemptions granted by this section to a moving vehicle shall apply only when the operator of such vehicle displays a flashing, blinking or alternating red light and sounds a siren, exhaust whistle or air horn designed to give automatically intermittent signals, as may be reasonably necessary, and only when there is in force and effect for such vehicle standard automobile liability insurance covering injury or death to any person in the sum of at least $100,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident and, subject to the limit for one person, to a limit of $300,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident, and to a limit of $10,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident. 
(c)  The exemptions granted by this section shall not protect the operator of such vehicle from criminal prosecution for conduct constituting reckless disregard of the safety of persons and property. Nothing in this section shall be construed to release the operator of any such vehicle from civil liability for failure to use reasonable care in such operation. 
(Code 1967, § 16-79; Code 1981, § 13-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-920. 
Sec. 32-6. - Adoption of state traffic laws. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313, all of the provisions and requirements of the laws of the state contained in title 46.2 of the Code of Virginia, as currently exist or as may hereafter be amended, except those provisions and requirements the violation of which constitutes a felony, and except those provisions and requirements which, by their very nature, can have no application to or within the city, are hereby adopted and incorporated in this chapter by reference and made applicable within the city. Reference to term "highways of the state" contained in such provisions and requirements are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as fully as though set forth at length herein, and it shall be unlawful for any person within the city to violate or fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any provision of title 46.2 of the Code of Virginia which is adopted by this section; provided, that in no event shall the penalty imposed for the violation of any provision or requirement hereby adopted exceed the penalty imposed for a similar offense under Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100 et seq. 
(b)  All definitions of words and phrases contained in the state law hereby adopted shall apply to such words and phrases, when used in this chapter, unless clearly indicated to the contrary. 
(Code 1967, § 16-1; Code 1981, § 13-6; Ord. No. 75-12, 7-24-1975; Ord. of 12-14-1989; Ord. of 6-13-1991; Ord. of 11-26-1996(02), § 13-6; Ord. of 9-12-2002(01); Ord. of 11-13-2003(01)) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state law by reverence, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313. 
Sec. 32-7. - Adoption of provisions regarding driving while under influence of alcohol or drugs. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313, all of the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 18.2-266 et seq., as may hereafter be amended, are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as though set out at length herein. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to violate the provisions of said article and section of the Code of Virginia, while operating a motor vehicle in an area subject to the jurisdiction of the court system of the city. 
(Code 1967, §§ 16-83-16-89; Code 1981, § 13-7; Ord. of 9-12-2002(02); Ord. of 11-13-2003(02)) 
State Law reference- General power of city to prohibit operation of vehicles while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1716; authority to adopt state law on the subject, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313. 
Sec. 32-8. - Powers of city manager. 
(a)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided by this chapter and except as otherwise directed, from time to time, by the city council, shall have power and is hereby authorized to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the corporate limits of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating prohibited or limited parking, angle parking, the parking of buses, trucks and other vehicles of various weights, U-turns, turning at intersections (including prohibited or required right or left turns), hazardous intersections, school zones, hospital zones, loading and unloading zones, quiet zones, traffic control signals exhibiting colored lights or the word "go," "caution" or "stop" and other signs or markers indicating the place and manner of operating or parking vehicles in the city. 
(b)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided by this chapter and except as otherwise directed, from time to time, by the city council, shall also have power and is hereby authorized to regulate the movement of pedestrians upon the streets and sidewalks of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic. 
(c)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided by this chapter and except as otherwise directed, from time to time, by the city council, shall also have power and is hereby authorized to designate bus stops and to erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses at such stops. 
(d)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided by this chapter and except as otherwise directed, from time to time, by the city council, is further empowered and authorized to mark off traffic lanes or streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic. 
(e)  The city manager shall further have power and is hereby authorized to secure all such necessary signs, signals or markers to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street. 
(Code 1967, § 16-6; Code 1981, § 13-9) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1300 et seq., 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 32-9. - Stop and yield intersections. 
(a)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided by this chapter and except as otherwise directed from time to time by the city council, may designate intersections at which vehicles shall come to a full stop or yield the right-of-way. 
(b)  The city manager shall further have power and is hereby authorized to secure all such necessary signs, signals or markers to be erected or placed on or at any such intersection, so that an ordinarily observant person, who may be affected by such regulation, may be aware of such regulation. 
(Code 1967, § 16-7; Code 1981, § 13-10) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1301. 
Sec. 32-10. - Signs, etc., authorized. 
    The existence of signs, signals or markers as described in the preceding two sections at any place within the corporate limits of the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs, signals or markers were erected or placed by and at the direction of the city manager in accordance with the provisions of such sections. 
(Code 1967, §§ 16-6, 16-7; Code 1981, § 13-11) 
State Law reference- Signs or markers must be visible, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1301. 
Sec. 32-11. - Compliance with signs, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with the directions indicated on any sign, signal or marker erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of sections 32-8-32-10 when such sign, signal or marker so placed or erected is visible and legible. 
(Code 1967, § 16-8; Code 1981, § 13-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-830. 
Sec. 32-12. - Permits for parades and processions. 
    No funeral procession or parade, excepting the forces of the United States Army or Navy, the military forces of the state and the forces of the police and fire departments of the city, shall occupy or march or proceed along any street, except in accordance with a permit issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 16-10; Code 1981, § 13-13) 
State Law reference- Power of city to permit the temporary use of streets for other than public purposes, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2013. 
Sec. 32-13. - Enforcement of chapter by police; officers not to benefit from fines. 
(a)  Every police officer shall enforce the provisions of this chapter; provided that such officer shall be uniformed at the time of such enforcement or shall display his badge or other sign of authority. All officers making arrests incident to the enforcement of this chapter shall be paid fixed salaries for their services and shall have no interest in, nor be permitted by law to accept the benefit of, any fine or fee resulting from the arrest or conviction of an offender against any provision of this chapter. 
(b)  With the consent of the landowner, any such officer or other uniformed employee of the police department may patrol the landowner's property to enforce state, county or city motor vehicle registration and licensing requirements. 
(c)  Any law enforcement officer may patrol the streets and roads within subdivisions of real property or within land submitted to a horizontal property regime pursuant to Code of Virginia, §§ 55-79.1 et seq., or 55-79.39 et seq., which streets and roads are maintained by the owners of the lots or parcels of land within the subdivision or the owners of condominium units within any horizontal property regime or any association of owners, on the request or with the consent of the owners or association of owners, to enforce the provisions of this chapter punishable as felonies, misdemeanors, or traffic infractions. 
(Code 1981, § 13-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-102. 
Sec. 32-14. - Authority of police generally. 
    Every police officer of this city is authorized to act as a traffic officer in the direction of traffic on any street where traffic is heavy or continuous, and the direction by such traffic officer shall take precedence over any lights or semaphores. 
(Code 1967, § 16-32; Code 1981, § 13-15) 
Sec. 32-15. - Regulation of traffic in subdivisions. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code to the contrary, there shall be in all subdivisions presently existing or hereafter established all necessary traffic signs, devices and controls, irrespective of ownership, in any street, right-of-way, easement, pedestrian way, parking area or other area open to the public. 
(b)  The police department of the city shall enforce all of the provisions of this chapter within all subdivisions, whether under the control of homeowners' associations or other associations maintaining their own streets, sidewalks, parking areas, recreation areas or their common areas or ways in public use, but not in public ownership. Any law enforcement officer properly enforcing the law shall not be subject to any civil or criminal action for trespassing while enforcing the law in or upon any property in public use but not in public ownership. 
(c)  This section shall apply to all existing and future residential subdivisions. All signs or other appropriate marking or devices regulating pedestrian traffic shall be prepared and installed, at expense of the owner, by the city manager in accordance with the provisions of sections 32-8-32-10. 
(Code 1981, § 13-16) 
State Law reference- Authority for section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1305. 
Sec. 32-16. - Direction of traffic by police officers and school crossing guards. 
(a)  Police officers and uniformed school crossing guards may direct traffic by signals. Such signals, other than by voice, shall be as follows: 
(1)  To stop traffic by hand. Stand with shoulders parallel to moving traffic. Raise arms 45 degrees above shoulder with hand extended, palm towards moving traffic to be stopped. 
(2)  To move traffic by hand. Stand with shoulders parallel to traffic to be moved. Extend right arm and hand full length at height of shoulders, towards such traffic, fingers extended and joined, palm down. Bring hand sharply in direction traffic is to move. Repeat movement with left arm and hand to start traffic from opposite direction. 
(3)  To stop and start traffic by whistles. One blast, moving traffic to stop; two blasts, traffic in opposite direction to move. 
(4)  Emergency stop of traffic by whistle. Three or more short blasts. All traffic shall immediately clear the intersection and stop. 
(b)  Such law enforcement officers and uniformed school crossing guards may also use supplemental traffic direction devices, including but not limited to handheld stop or go signs, in directing traffic as provided in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 16-34; Code 1981, § 13-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1309. 
Sec. 32-17. - Authority of chief of police to deputize persons to direct traffic. 
(a)  The chief of police may deputize persons over the age of 18 years, without the power of arrest, for the limited purpose of directing traffic in accordance with the preceding section during periods of heavy traffic or congestion, provided such persons first receive such training as the chief of police determines necessary to fully acquaint such persons with the techniques of traffic control. They shall not have arrest powers. 
(b)  Any person who is deputized as provided in this section shall, at all times while engaged in traffic control, wear a distinctive police uniform, safety vest or a white reflectorized belt which crosses both the chest and back above the waist. 
(Code 1981, § 13-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1310. 
Sec. 32-18. - Minimum age for drivers of school buses and passenger carriers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether licensed or not, who is under the age of 18 years to drive a motor vehicle while in use as: 
(1)  A school bus for the transportation of pupils; or 
(2)  Public passenger-carrying vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 13-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-919, 46.2-810. 
Sec. 32-19. - Vehicle motor numbers and identification numbers; required; specifications. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or to operate upon any highway in this city, any motor vehicle which does not have stamped upon or cut into the motor thereof the motor number or which does not bear a permanent serial or other identification number assigned thereto by the manufacturer or by the commissioner, or any trailer or semitrailer which does not bear a permanent serial or other identification number assigned thereto by the manufacturer thereof or by the commissioner. Such number shall be stamped, cut, embossed or attached in such a manner that it cannot be changed, altered or removed without plainly showing evidence which would be readily detectable or which would destroy the attached plate. Such number shall be die stamped, cut or embossed into or attached to a permanent part of the vehicle, which is easily accessible for checking or verification. 
(b)  Nonresident owners who are permitted to operate motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers without registration, under the registration provisions relating to nonresidents contained in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-655 through 46.2-661, shall not be required to comply with the provisions of this section before operating a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer upon the highways of this city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-22; Code 1981, § 13-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1072. 
Sec. 32-20. - Inspection of vehicles. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer operated upon a highway within this state shall submit such vehicle to an inspection of its mechanism and equipment by an official inspection station designated for that purpose in accordance with Code of Virginia § 46.2-1158. No owner or operator of any such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer operated or parked upon the highways of this city shall fail to submit such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer to such inspection, or fail or refuse to correct or have corrected, in accordance with the requirements of this chapter or of state law, any mechanical defects found by such inspection to exist. Each day that such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is operated or parked on any highway of the city after failure to comply with this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be as provided in Code of Virginia § 46.2-1158.02. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to vehicles exempt pursuant to Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1158.01 and 46.2-1159. 
(Code 1967, § 16-25; Code 1981, § 13-21) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1157, 46.2-1158.02. 
Sec. 32-21. - Unauthorized taking, possession or use of inspection stickers. 
(a)  No person shall, within this city, remove from the custody of any person to whom the same has been issued by or under authority of the superintendent, nor have in his possession or use otherwise than as authorized by the superintendent, the sticker or other form of paper issued by the superintendent in connection with the inspection of motor vehicles. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 16-26; Code 1981, § 13-22) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1172. 
Sec. 32-22. - Imitation or counterfeit inspection sticker; use of sticker issued for another vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall make, issue or knowingly use any imitation or counterfeit of any official safety inspection sticker. 
(b)  No person shall display or cause or permit to be displayed upon any vehicle any safety inspection sticker knowing it to be fictitious or issued for another vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 16-27; Code 1981, § 13-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1173. 
Sec. 32-23. - Authority of police to stop vehicles for inspection or to secure information. 
(a)  Except as prohibited by Code of Virginia, § 19.2-59, on request or signal, any law enforcement officer who is in uniform or displays his badge or other sign of authority may stop any: 
(1)  Motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer to inspect its equipment, operation, manufacturer's serial or engine number; or 
(2)  Property-carrying motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer to inspect its contents or load or to obtain other necessary information. 
(b)  Nothing in this section, however, shall be construed to authorize the establishment on any highway of police checkpoints where the only vehicles subject to inspection are motorcycles 
(Code 1967, § 16-11; Code 1981, § 13-24) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-103. 
Sec. 32-24. - Records required of persons renting motor vehicles without drivers. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of renting motor vehicles without drivers, who shall rent any such vehicle without a driver, otherwise than as a part of a bona fide transaction involving the sale of such motor vehicle, shall maintain a record of the identity of the person to whom the vehicle is rented and the exact time the vehicle is the subject of such rental or in possession of the person renting and having the use of the vehicle. Every such record shall be a public record and open to inspection by any person damaged as to his person or property by the operation of the vehicle or by any member of the police department in the discharge of his duty. Any person who has been damaged as to his person or property may require a production of such written record upon application in person or by his duly authorized agent or attorney. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who shall rent a motor vehicle as provided in this section to fail to make or have in possession, or to refuse an inspection of, the record required in this section. 
(c)  The owner shall use such forms for the keeping of the record provided for in this section as shall be prescribed by the commissioner of the department of motor vehicles of this state or by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 13-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-108. 
Sec. 32-25. - Lettering on certain vehicles including tow trucks. 
(a)  No person shall drive, cause to be driven, or permit the driving of a "for hire" motor vehicle on the highways in the city unless the name and address of the owner of the vehicle is plainly displayed on both sides of the vehicle. The letters and numerals in the display shall be of such size, shape, and color as to be readily legible during daylight hours from a distance of 50 feet while the vehicle is not in motion. The display shall be kept legible and may take the form of a removable device which meets the identification and legibility requirements of this section. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle: 
(1)  Having a registered gross weight of less than 10,000 pounds; 
(2)  Which is used exclusively for wedding, ambulance or funeral services; or 
(3)  Which is rented without chauffeur and operated under a valid lease which gives the lessee exclusive control of the vehicle. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the exemptions contained in subsection (b) of this section, the requirements of subsection (a) of this section shall also apply to all motor vehicles leased to common or contract carriers of persons or property which are required to operate under certificates or permits issued by the state corporation commission or the interstate commerce commission. 
(d)  Subsection (a) of this section shall also apply to tow trucks used in providing service to the public for hire. For the purposes of this section, the term "tow truck" means any motor vehicle which is constructed and used primarily for towing, lifting or otherwise moving disabled vehicles. 
(e)  No person shall drive on the highways in the city a pickup or panel truck, tractor truck, trailer, or semitrailer bearing any name other than that of the vehicle's owner or lessee. However, the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to advertising material for another, displayed pursuant to a valid contract. 
(Code 1967, § 16-17; Code 1981, §§ 13-26-13-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1076. 
Sec. 32-26. - Occupation of trailer being towed on streets or highways. 
    No person shall occupy a house trailer or camping trailer while such trailer is being towed upon a public street or highway, and no operator of a towing vehicle shall knowingly permit another person to do such In any civil proceeding, the violation hereof shall not constitute negligence per se. 
(Code 1981, § 13-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-813. 
Sec. 32-27. - Inoperable vehicles; removal. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer which: 
(1)  Is not in operating condition; 
(2)  Which for a period of 60 days or longer has been partially or totally disassembled by the removal of tires and wheels, the engine or other essential parts required for operation of the vehicle; or 
(3)  Does not display an inspection decal that is valid or does display an inspection decal that has been expired for more than 60 days. 
    Shielded or screened from public view means not visible by someone standing at ground level from outside of the property on which the subject vehicle is located. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to keep, except within a fully enclosed building or structure or otherwise shielded or screened from public view, or any property zoned for residential or commercial or agricultural purposes, any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, as such is defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, as amended, which is inoperable. However, the provisions of this section shall not apply to a licensed business which on June 26, 1970, was regularly engaged in business as an automobile dealer, salvage dealer or scrap processor. It is further provided by this section that the owners of the property zoned for residential, commercial or agricultural purposes shall remove from such property any inoperable motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers that are not kept within a fully enclosed building or structure. The city, through its agents or employees, may remove any such inoperable vehicles, trailers or semitrailers, whenever the owner of the premises, after receiving a 30-day notice, has failed to do so. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, if the owner of such vehicle can demonstrate that he is actively restoring or repairing the vehicle, and if it is shielded or screened from view, the vehicle and one additional inoperative motor vehicle that is shielded or screened from view and being used for the restoration or repair may remain on the property. 
(d)  In the event the city, through its agents or employees, removes any such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers, after having given 30 days' notice, the city may dispose of such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers after giving additional notice to the owner of the vehicle. The cost of any such removal and disposal shall be chargeable either to the owner of the vehicle or the owner of the premises and may be collected by the city as taxes and levies are collected. The costs authorized by this section with which the owner of the premises shall have been assessed shall constitute a lien against the property from which the vehicle was removed, the lien to continue until actual payment of such costs shall have been made to the city. 
(Code 1981, § 13-30; Ord. of 9-23-1992) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict keeping of inoperable vehicles on residential, commercial or agricultural property, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-904. 
Sec. 32-28. - Traffic infractions treated as misdemeanors for arrest purposes. 
    For purposes of arrest, traffic infractions shall be treated as misdemeanors. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, the authority and duties of arresting officers shall be the same for traffic infractions as for misdemeanors. 
(Code 1981, § 13-35) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-937. 
Sec. 32-29. - Arrest procedure for violation of chapter. 
(a)  Whenever any person is detained by or in the custody of an arresting officer, including an arrest on a warrant, for a violation of any provision of this chapter, except as otherwise provided in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-940 and section 32-547, the arresting officer shall, except as otherwise provided in section 32-31, or any other section of this chapter, take the name and address of such person and the license number of his motor vehicle and issue a summons or otherwise notify him in writing to appear at a time and place to be specified in such summons or notice, such time to be at least five days after such arrest unless the person arrested shall demand an earlier hearing and such person shall, if he so desires, have a right to an immediate hearing or a hearing within 24 hours at a convenient hour, and before a court having jurisdiction. Such officer shall thereupon, and upon giving by such person of his written promise to appear at such time and place, forthwith release him from custody. 
(b)  Any person refusing to give a written promise to appear as provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be taken immediately by the arresting or other police officer before the nearest or most accessible judicial officer or other person qualified to admit to bail having jurisdiction under this chapter. 
(c)  Any person who willfully violates his written promise to appear, given in accordance with this section, shall be treated in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 46.2-938. 
(d)  Any officer violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of misconduct in office and subject to removal therefrom upon complaint filed by any person in a court of competent jurisdiction. This section shall not be construed to limit the removal of a police officer for other misconduct in office. 
(Code 1967, § 16-29; Code 1981, § 13-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936. 
Sec. 32-30. - Insurance of warrant upon failure to comply with summons; suspension of license for failure to appear. 
(a)  Upon the failure of any person to comply with the terms of a summons or notice as provided in the preceding section, the court may direct the arresting officer or the clerk of the court to obtain a warrant for his arrest or for the violation of his written promise to appear given in accordance with such section and serve, or cause to be served, or attempt, or cause to be attempted, to serve such warrant on the person. The warrant shall be returnable to the court having jurisdiction of the offense and shall be accompanied by a report by the arresting officer which shall clearly identify the person arrested, specifying the section of this chapter violated, the location of the offense, a description of the motor vehicle and its registration or license number. 
(b)  If the warrant is returned to the court with the notation "not found" or the person named in the warrant does not appear on the return date thereof, the court shall forward a certificate of the fact of nonservice or nonappearance, with a copy of the report specified in subsection (a) of this section, to the commissioner, who shall forthwith suspend the driver's license of such person. The order of suspension shall specify the reason for the suspension. Such suspension shall continue until such time as the court has notified the commissioner that the defendant has appeared before the court under the terms of the summons or notice and the warrant. 
(Code 1981, § 13-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-938. 
Sec. 32-31. - When arrested person to be taken before judicial officer. 
    If any person arrested for a violation of this chapter is believed by the arresting officer to have committed a felony; believed by the arresting officer to be likely to disregard a summons issued under section 32-29, or refuses to give a written promise to appear under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936 or 46.2-945, the arresting officer shall promptly take such person forthwith before a magistrate or other issuing authority having jurisdiction and proceed in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 19.2-82. The magistrate or other authority may issue either a summons or warrant as he shall determine proper. 
(Code 1967, § 16-30; Code 1981, § 13-38) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-940. 
Secs. 32-32-32-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STATE REGISTRATION AND LICENSING OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Registration and licensing of vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-600 et seq. 

Sec. 32-53. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or for the owner thereof to knowingly permit the operation of, upon a highway within the city, any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by him which is not registered or for which a certificate of title has not been issued, whenever such registration or certificate of title is required by state law or it does not have displayed on it the license plate or plates and decal or decals, if any, assigned to it by the state department for the current registration period, subject to the exemptions mentioned in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-655 et seq., and 46.2-662 et seq. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display, cause or permit to be displayed, any registration card, certificate of title, or license plate or decal which he knows is fictitious or which he knows has been cancelled, revoked, suspended, or altered; or display or cause or permit to be displayed on any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer any license plate or decal that he knows is currently issued for another vehicle. Violation of this subsection shall constitute a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or lend or knowingly permit the use of any registration card, license plate, or decal by anyone not entitled to it. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to surrender to the department or the department of state police, on demand, any certificate of title, registration card, or license plate or decal which has been suspended, cancelled or revoked. Violation of this subsection shall constitute a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a false name or address in any application for the registration of any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer or for a certificate of title or for any renewal or duplicate certificate, or knowingly to make a false statement of a material fact or to conceal a material fact or otherwise commit a fraud in any registration application. Violation of this subsection shall constitute a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 16-13; Code 1981, § 13-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-613. 
Sec. 32-54. - New certificate of title after substitution of motor. 
    Each holder of a certificate of title of a motor vehicle who shall substitute in such vehicle another motor, so that such motor vehicle no longer conforms to the description contained in the application for the certificate of title, shall, promptly after such change is made, secure a new certificate of title. 
(Code 1981, § 13-52) 
Sec. 32-55. - Sale of vehicle without having certificate of title. 
    Except as provided in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-644.03 and 58.1-3942, any person who shall sell, trade, exchange or barter a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer in this city, without first having secured a certificate of title for it or without legally having in his possession a certificate of title for it issued to the owner thereof, except as otherwise provided in this chapter or in title 46.2 of the Code of Virginia, shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 16-23; Code 1981, § 13-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-617. 
Sec. 32-56. - Purchasing vehicle from vendor who does not have certificate of title.
